observed_pattern.description: The specific pattern identified within the observation type. For Frequency Analysis, this could be 'FREQUENT', 'INFREQUENT', 'RARE', or 'UNSEEN'. For Time Pattern Analysis, this could be 'BUSINESS_HOURS', 'OFF_HOURS', or 'UNUSUAL_TIME'. For Volume Analysis, this could be 'NORMAL_VOLUME', 'HIGH_VOLUME', or 'SURGE'. The pattern values are specific to each observation type and indicate the baseline behavior.

campaign.caption: Campaign
campaign.description: Campaign represent organized efforts by threat actors to achieve malicious objectives over a period, often characterized by shared tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs).
campaign.name: campaign

name.description: The name of a specific campaign associated with a cyber threat.

certificate.caption: Digital Certificate
certificate.description: The Digital Certificate, also known as a Public Key Certificate, object contains information about the ownership and usage of a public key. It serves as a means to establish trust in the authenticity and integrity of the public key and the associated entity.
certificate.name: certificate

created_time.description: The time when the certificate was created.

expiration_time.description: The expiration time of the certificate.

fingerprints.description: The fingerprint list of the certificate.

sans.caption: Subject Alternative Names
sans.description: The list of subject alternative names that are secured by a specific certificate.

serial_number.caption: Certificate Serial Number
serial_number.description: The serial number of the certificate used to create the digital signature.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the certificate.

version.description: The certificate version.

check.caption: Check
check.description: The check object defines a specific, testable compliance verification point that evaluates a target device against a standard, framework, or custom requirement. While checks are typically associated with formal standards (like CIS, NIST, or ISO), they can also represent custom or organizational requirements. When mapped to controls, checks can evaluate specific control_parameters to determine compliance status, but neither the control mapping nor control_parameters are required for a valid check.
check.name: check

desc.description: The detailed description of the compliance check, explaining the security requirement, vulnerability, or configuration being assessed. For example, CIS: The cramfs filesystem type is a compressed read-only Linux filesystem. Removing support for unneeded filesystem types reduces the local attack surface. or DISA STIG: Unauthorized access to the information system by foreign entities may result in loss or compromise of data.

name.description: The name or title of the compliance check. For example, CIS: Ensure mounting of cramfs filesystems is disabled or DISA STIG: The Ubuntu operating system must implement DoD-approved encryption to protect the confidentiality of remote access sessions.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the compliance check within its standard or framework. For example, CIS Benchmark identifier 1.1.1.1, DISA STIG identifier V-230234, or NIST control identifier AC-17(2).

version.description: The check version. For example, CIS Benchmark: 1.1.0 for Amazon Linux 2 or DISA STIG: V2R1 for Windows 10.

standards.description: The regulatory or industry standard this check is associated with. E.g., PCI DSS 3.2.1, HIPAA Security Rule, NIST SP 800-53 Rev. 5, or ISO/IEC 27001:2013.

status.description: The resultant status of the compliance check normalized to the caption of the status_id value. For example, CIS Benchmark: Pass when all requirements are met, Fail when requirements are not met, or DISA STIG: NotAFinding (maps to status_id 1/Pass), Open (maps to status_id 3/Fail).

status_id.description: The normalized status identifier of the compliance check.

1.caption: Pass
1.description: The compliance check passed for all the evaluated resources.

2.caption: Warning
2.description: The compliance check did not yield a result due to missing information.

3.caption: Fail
3.description: The compliance check failed for at least one of the evaluated resources.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The event status is not mapped. See the status attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

severity.description: The severity level as defined in the source document. For example CIS Benchmarks, valid values are: Level 1 (security-forward, essential settings), Level 2 (security-focused environment, more restrictive), or Scored/Not Scored (whether compliance can be automatically checked). For DISA STIG, valid values are: CAT I (maps to severity_id 5/Critical), CAT II (maps to severity_id 4/High), or CAT III (maps to severity_id 3/Medium).

severity_id.description: The normalized severity identifier that maps severity levels to standard severity levels. For example CIS Benchmark: Level 2 maps to 4 (High), Level 1 maps to 3 (Medium). For DISA STIG: CAT I maps to 5 (Critical), CAT II maps to 4 (High), and CAT III maps to 3 (Medium).

1.caption: Informational
1.description: Informational message. No action required.

2.caption: Low
2.description: The user decides if action is needed.

3.caption: Medium
3.description: Maps to CIS Benchmark Level 1 - Essential security settings recommended for all systems, or DISA STIG CAT III - Action is required but the situation is not serious at this time.

4.caption: High
4.description: Maps to CIS Benchmark Level 2 - More restrictive and security-focused settings for sensitive environments, or DISA STIG CAT II - Action is required immediately.

5.caption: Critical
5.description: Maps to DISA STIG CAT I - Action is required immediately and the scope is broad.

6.caption: Fatal
6.description: An error occurred but it is too late to take remedial action.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The severity is not mapped. See the severity attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

cis_benchmark.caption: CIS Benchmark
cis_benchmark.description: The CIS Benchmark object describes best practices for securely configuring IT systems, software, networks, and cloud infrastructure as defined by the Center for Internet Security. See also Getting to Know the CIS Benchmarks.
cis_benchmark.name: cis_benchmark

@deprecated.message: Use the Compliance object with Checks object instead.

desc.description: The CIS Benchmark description. For example: The cramfs filesystem type is a compressed read-only Linux filesystem embedded in small footprint systems. A cramfs image can be used without having to first decompress the image.

name.description: The CIS Benchmark name. For example: Ensure mounting of cramfs filesystems is disabled.

cis_benchmark_result.caption: CIS Benchmark Result
cis_benchmark_result.description: The CIS Benchmark Result object contains information as defined by the Center for Internet Security (CIS) benchmark result. CIS Benchmarks are a collection of best practices for securely configuring IT systems, software, networks, and cloud infrastructure.
cis_benchmark_result.name: cis_benchmark_result

@deprecated.message: Use the Compliance object with Checks object instead.

desc.description: The CIS benchmark description.

name.description: The CIS benchmark name.

cis_control.caption: CIS Control
cis_control.description: The CIS Control (aka Critical Security Control) object describes a prioritized set of actions to protect your organization and data from cyber-attack vectors. The CIS Controls are defined by the Center for Internet Security.
cis_control.name: cis_control

desc.description: The CIS Control description. For example: Uninstall or disable unnecessary services on enterprise assets and software, such as an unused file sharing service, web application module, or service function.

name.description: The CIS Control name. For example: 4.8 Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software.

version.description: The CIS Control version. For example: v8.

cis_csc.caption: CIS CSC
cis_csc.description: The CIS Critical Security Control (CSC) contains information as defined by the Center for Internet Security Critical Security Control (CIS CSC). Prioritized set of actions to protect your organization and data from cyber-attack vectors.
cis_csc.name: cis_csc

version.description: The CIS critical security control version.

classifier_details.caption: Classifier Details
classifier_details.description: The Classifier Details object describes details about the classifier used for data classification.
classifier_details.name: classifier_details

name.description: The name of the classifier.

type.description: The type of the classifier.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the classifier.

cloud.caption: Cloud
cloud.description: The Cloud object contains information about a cloud or Software-as-a-Service account or similar construct, such as AWS Account ID, regions, organizations, folders, compartments, tenants, etc.
cloud.name: cloud

provider.description: The unique name of the Cloud services provider, such as AWS, MS Azure, GCP, etc.

region.description: The name of the cloud region, as defined by the cloud provider.

zone.caption: Cloud Availability Zone
zone.description: The availability zone in the cloud region, as defined by the cloud provider.

compliance.caption: Compliance
compliance.description: The Compliance object contains information about Industry and Regulatory Framework standards, controls and requirements or details about custom assessments utilized in a compliance evaluation. Standards define broad security frameworks, controls represent specific security requirements within those frameworks, and checks are the testable verification points used to determine if controls are properly implemented.
compliance.name: compliance

assessments.description: A list of assessments associated with the compliance requirements evaluation.

category.description: The category a control framework pertains to, as reported by the source tool, such as Asset Management or Risk Assessment.

checks.description: A list of compliance checks associated with specific industry standards or frameworks. Each check represents an individual rule or requirement that has been evaluated against a target device. Checks typically include details such as the check name (e.g., CIS: 'Ensure mounting of cramfs filesystems is disabled' or DISA STIG descriptive titles), unique identifiers (such as CIS identifier '1.1.1.1' or DISA STIG identifier 'V-230234'), descriptions (detailed explanations of security requirements or vulnerability discussions), and version information.

@deprecated.message: Use the Compliance object with Check array instead.
Use the Compliance object with Check array instead.

control.description: A Control is a prescriptive, actionable set of specifications that strengthens device posture. The control specifies required security measures, while the specific implementation values are defined in control_parameters. E.g., CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark 1.2.0 - Control 2.1 - Ensure CloudTrail is enabled in all regions

control_parameters.description: The list of control parameters evaluated in a Compliance check. E.g., parameters for CloudTrail configuration might include multiRegionTrailEnabled: true, logFileValidationEnabled: true, and requiredRegions: [us-east-1, us-west-2]

desc.description: The description or criteria of a control.

requirements.description: The specific compliance requirements being evaluated. E.g., PCI DSS Requirement 8.2.3 - Passwords must meet minimum complexity requirements or HIPAA Security Rule 164.312(a)(2)(iv) - Implement encryption and decryption mechanisms

standards.description: The regulatory or industry standards being evaluated for compliance.

status.description: The resultant status of the compliance check normalized to the caption of the status_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

status_code.description: The resultant status code of the compliance check.

status_detail.description: The contextual description of the status, status_code values.

status_details.description: A list of contextual descriptions of the status, status_code values.

status_id.description: The normalized status identifier of the compliance check.

1.caption: Pass
1.description: The compliance check passed for all the evaluated resources.

2.caption: Warning
2.description: The compliance check did not yield a result due to missing information.

3.caption: Fail
3.description: The compliance check failed for at least one of the evaluated resources.

container.caption: Container
container.description: The Container object describes an instance of a specific container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.
container.name: container

hash.description: Commit hash of image created for docker or the SHA256 hash of the container. For example: 13550340a8681c84c861aac2e5b440161c2b33a3e4f302ac680ca5b686de48de.

image.description: The container image used as a template to run the container.

labels.description: The list of labels associated to the container.

name.description: The container name.

size.description: The size of the container image.

tag.description: The tag used by the container. It can indicate version, format, OS.

tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the container.

uid.description: The full container unique identifier for this instantiation of the container. For example: ac2ea168264a08f9aaca0dfc82ff3551418dfd22d02b713142a6843caa2f61bf.

cve.caption: CVE
cve.description: The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) object represents publicly disclosed cybersecurity vulnerabilities defined in CVE Program catalog (CVE). There is one CVE Record for each vulnerability in the catalog.
cve.name: cve

created_time.description: The Record Creation Date identifies when the CVE ID was issued to a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA) or the CVE Record was published on the CVE List. Note that the Record Creation Date does not necessarily indicate when this vulnerability was discovered, shared with the affected vendor, publicly disclosed, or updated in CVE.

desc.description: A brief description of the CVE Record.

modified_time.description: The Record Modified Date identifies when the CVE record was last updated.

product.description: The product where the vulnerability was discovered.

references.description: A list of reference URLs with additional information about the CVE Record.

related_cwes.description: Describes the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) details related to the CVE Record.

title.description: A title or a brief phrase summarizing the CVE record.

type.caption: Vulnerability Type
type.description:
The vulnerability type as selected from a large dropdown menu during CVE refinement.

Most frequently used vulnerability types are: DoS, Code Execution, Overflow, Memory Corruption, Sql Injection, XSS, Directory Traversal, Http Response Splitting, Bypass something, Gain Information, Gain Privileges, CSRF, File Inclusion. For more information see Vulnerabilities By Type distributions.

uid.caption: CVE ID
uid.description: The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures unique number assigned to a specific computer vulnerability. A CVE Identifier begins with 4 digits representing the year followed by a sequence of digits that acts as a unique identifier. For example: CVE-2021-12345.

cvss.caption: CVSS Score
cvss.description: The Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) object provides a way to capture the principal characteristics of a vulnerability and produce a numerical score reflecting its severity.
cvss.name: cvss

base_score.description: The CVSS base score. For example: 9.1.

metrics.description: The Common Vulnerability Scoring System metrics. This attribute contains information on the CVE's impact. If the CVE has been analyzed, this attribute will contain any CVSSv2 or CVSSv3 information associated with the vulnerability. For example: { {"Access Vector", "Network"}, {"Access Complexity", "Low"}, ...}.

overall_score.description: The CVSS overall score, impacted by base, temporal, and environmental metrics. For example: 9.1.

severity.description:
The Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) Qualitative Severity Rating. A textual representation of the numeric score.

CVSS v2.0
  • Low (0.0 – 3.9)
  • Medium (4.0 – 6.9)
  • High (7.0 – 10.0)

CVSS v3.0
  • None (0.0)
  • Low (0.1 - 3.9)
  • Medium (4.0 - 6.9)
  • High (7.0 - 8.9)
  • Critical (9.0 - 10.0)

src_url.description: The source URL for the CVSS score. For example: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-44228

vendor_name.description: The vendor that provided the CVSS score. For example: NVD, REDHAT etc.

version.description: The CVSS version. For example: 3.1.

cwe.caption: CWE
cwe.description: The CWE object represents a weakness in a software system that can be exploited by a threat actor to perform an attack. The CWE object is based on the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) catalog.
cwe.name: cwe

caption.description: The caption assigned to the Common Weakness Enumeration unique identifier.

src_url.description: URL pointing to the CWE Specification. For more information see CWE.

uid.caption: CWE ID
uid.description: The Common Weakness Enumeration unique number assigned to a specific weakness. A CWE Identifier begins "CWE" followed by a sequence of digits that acts as a unique identifier. For example: CWE-123.

d3f_tactic.caption: MITRE D3FEND™ Tactic
d3f_tactic.description: The MITRE D3FEND™ Tactic object describes the tactic ID and/or name that is associated to an attack.
d3f_tactic.name: d3f_tactic

name.description: The tactic name that is associated with the defensive technique. For example: Isolate.

src_url.description: The versioned permalink of the defensive tactic. For example: https://d3fend.mitre.org/tactic/d3f:Isolate/.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the defensive tactic.

d3f_technique.caption: MITRE D3FEND™ Technique
d3f_technique.description: The MITRE D3FEND™ Technique object describes the leaf defensive technique ID and/or name associated to a countermeasure.
d3f_technique.name: d3f_technique

name.description: The name of the defensive technique. For example: IO Port Restriction.

src_url.description: The versioned permalink of the defensive technique. For example: https://d3fend.mitre.org/technique/d3f:IOPortRestriction/.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the defensive technique. For example: D3-IOPR.

d3fend.caption: MITRE D3FEND™
d3fend.description: The MITRE D3FEND™ object describes the tactic & technique associated with a countermeasure.
d3fend.name: d3fend

d3f_tactic.description: The Tactic object describes the tactic ID and/or name that is associated with a countermeasure.

d3f_technique.description: The Technique object describes the technique ID and/or name associated with a countermeasure.

version.description: The D3FEND™ Matrix version.

data_classification.caption: Data Classification
data_classification.description: The Data Classification object includes information about data classification levels and data category types.
data_classification.name: data_classification

category.description: The name of the data classification category that data matched into, e.g. Financial, Personal, Governmental, etc.

category_id.description: The normalized identifier of the data classification category.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The type is not mapped. See the data_type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

1.caption: Personal
1.description: Any Personally Identifiable Information (PII), Electronic Personal Health Information (ePHI), or similarly personal information. E.g., full name, home address, date of birth, etc.

2.caption: Governmental
2.description: Any sensitive government identification number related to a person or other classified material. E.g., Passport numbers, driver license numbers, business identification, taxation identifiers, etc.

3.caption: Financial
3.description: Any financially-related sensitive information or Cardholder Data (CHD). E.g., banking account numbers, credit card numbers, International Banking Account Numbers (IBAN), SWIFT codes, etc.

4.caption: Business
4.description: Any business-specific sensitive data such as intellectual property, trademarks, copyrights, human resource data, Board of Directors meeting minutes, and similar.

5.caption: Military and Law Enforcement
5.description: Any mission-specific sensitive data for military, law enforcement, or other government agencies such as specifically classified data, weapon systems information, or other planning data.

6.caption: Security
6.description: Any sensitive security-related data such as passwords, passkeys, IP addresses, API keys, credentials and similar secrets. E.g., AWS Access Secret Key, SaaS API Keys, user passwords, database credentials, etc.

99.caption: Other
99.description: Any other type of data classification or a multi-variate classification made up of several other classification categories.

discovery_details.description: Details about the data discovered by classification job.

policy.description: Details about the data policy that governs data handling and security measures related to classification.

src_url.description: The source URL pointing towards the full classifcation job details.

status.description: The resultant status of the classification job normalized to the caption of the status_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

status_details.description: The contextual description of the status, status_id value.

status_id.description: The normalized status identifier of the classification job.

1.caption: Complete
1.description: The classification job completed for the evaluated resource.

2.caption: Partial
2.description: The classification job partially completed for the evaluated resource.

3.caption: Fail
3.description: The classification job failed for the evaluated resource.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The classification job type id is not mapped.

total.description: The total count of discovered entities, by the classification job.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the classification job.

data_security.caption: Data Security
data_security.description: The Data Security object describes the characteristics, techniques and content of a Data Loss Prevention (DLP), Data Loss Detection (DLD), Data Classification, or similar tools' finding, alert, or detection mechanism(s).
data_security.name: data_security

policy.description: Details about the policy that triggered the finding.

database.caption: Database
database.description: The database object is used for databases which are typically datastore services that contain an organized collection of structured and unstructured data or a types of data.
database.name: database

created_time.description: The time when the database was known to have been created.

desc.description: The description of the database.

groups.description: The group names to which the database belongs.

modified_time.description: The most recent time when any changes, updates, or modifications were made within the database.

name.description: The database name, ordinarily as assigned by a database administrator.

size.description: The size of the database in bytes.

type.description: The database type.

type_id.description: The normalized identifier of the database type.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the database.

databucket.caption: Databucket
databucket.description: The databucket object is a basic container that holds data, typically organized through the use of data partitions.
databucket.name: databucket

created_time.description: The time when the databucket was known to have been created.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: The description of the databucket.

encryption_details.description: The encryption details of the databucket. Should be populated if the databucket is encrypted.

file.description: Details about the file/object within a databucket.

groups.description: The group names to which the databucket belongs.

is_encrypted.description: Indicates if the databucket is encrypted.

is_public.description: Indicates if the databucket is publicly accessible.

modified_time.description: The most recent time when any changes, updates, or modifications were made within the databucket.

name.description: The databucket name.

size.description: The size of the databucket in bytes.

type.description: The databucket type.

type_id.description: The normalized identifier of the databucket type.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the databucket.

dce_rpc.caption: DCE/RPC
dce_rpc.description: The DCE/RPC, or Distributed Computing Environment/Remote Procedure Call, object describes the remote procedure call system for distributed computing environments.
dce_rpc.name: dce_rpc

command_response.description: The reply to the request command (e.g. RESPONSE, BINDACK or FAULT).

device.caption: Device
device.description: The Device object represents an addressable computer system or host, which is typically connected to a computer network and participates in the transmission or processing of data within the computer network.
device.name: device

boot_time.description: The time the system was booted.

created_time.description: The time when the device was known to have been created.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: The description of the device, ordinarily as reported by the operating system.

domain.description: The network domain where the device resides. For example: work.example.com.

first_seen_time.description: The initial discovery time of the device.

groups.description: The group names to which the device belongs. For example: ["Windows Laptops", "Engineering"].

image.description: The image used as a template to run the virtual machine.

ip.description: The device IP address, in either IPv4 or IPv6 format.

last_seen_time.description: The most recent discovery time of the device.

location.description: The geographical location of the device.

model.description: The model of the device. For example ThinkPad X1 Carbon.

modified_time.description: The time when the device was last known to have been modified.

name.description:
The alternate device name, ordinarily as assigned by an administrator.

Note: The Name could be any other string that helps to identify the device, such as a phone number; for example 310-555-1234.

org.description: Organization and org unit related to the device.

region.description: The region where the virtual machine is located. For example, an AWS Region.

type.description: The device type. For example: unknown, server, desktop, laptop, tablet, mobile, virtual, browser, or other.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the device. For example the Windows TargetSID or AWS EC2 ARN.

uid_alt.description: An alternate unique identifier of the device if any. For example the ActiveDirectory DN.

vendor_name.description: The vendor for the device. For example Dell or Lenovo.

device_hw_info.caption: Device Hardware Info
device_hw_info.description: The Device Hardware Information object contains details and specifications of the physical components that make up a device. This information provides an overview of the hardware capabilities, configuration, and characteristics of the device.
device_hw_info.name: device_hw_info

uuid.description: The device manufacturer assigned universally unique hardware identifier. For SMBIOS compatible devices such as those running Linux and Windows, it is the UUID member of the System Information structure in the SMBIOS information. For macOS devices, it is the Hardware UUID (also known as IOPlatformUUID in the I/O Registry).

references.description: macOS I/O Registry source code reference to IOPlatformUUID

digital_signature.caption: Digital Signature
digital_signature.description: The Digital Signature object contains information about the cryptographic mechanism used to verify the authenticity, integrity, and origin of the file or application.
digital_signature.name: digital_signature

algorithm.description: The digital signature algorithm used to create the signature, normalized to the caption of 'algorithm_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

algorithm_id.description: The identifier of the normalized digital signature algorithm.

1.caption: DSA
1.description: Digital Signature Algorithm (DSA).

2.caption: RSA
2.description: Rivest-Shamir-Adleman (RSA) Algorithm.

3.caption: ECDSA
3.description: Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm.

4.caption: Authenticode
4.description: Microsoft Authenticode Digital Signature Algorithm.

created_time.description: The time when the digital signature was created.

state.description: The digital signature state defines the signature state, normalized to the caption of 'state_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

state_id.description: The normalized identifier of the signature state.

1.caption: Valid
1.description: The digital signature is valid.

2.caption: Expired
2.description: The digital signature is not valid due to expiration of certificate.

3.caption: Revoked
3.description: The digital signature is invalid due to certificate revocation.

4.caption: Suspended
4.description: The digital signature is invalid due to certificate suspension.

5.caption: Pending
5.description: The digital signature state is pending.

discovery_details.caption: Discovery Details
discovery_details.description: The Discovery Details object describes results of a discovery task/job.
discovery_details.name: discovery_details

count.description: The number of discovered entities of the specified type.

occurrence_details.description: Details about where in the target entity, specified information was discovered. Only the attributes, relevant to the target entity type should be populuated.

occurrences.description: Details about where in the target entity, specified information was discovered. Only the attributes, relevant to the target entity type should be populuated.

type.description: The specific type of information that was discovered. e.g. name, phone_number, etc.

value.description: Optionally, the specific value of discovered information.

display.caption: Display
display.description: The Display object contains information about the physical or virtual display connected to a computer system.
display.name: display

dns_answer.caption: DNS Answer
dns_answer.description: The DNS Answer object represents a specific response provided by the Domain Name System (DNS) when querying for information about a domain or performing a DNS operation. It encapsulates the relevant details and data returned by the DNS server in response to a query.
dns_answer.name: dns_answer

class.description: The class of DNS data contained in this resource record. See RFC1035. For example: IN.

flag_ids.caption: DNS Header Flags
flag_ids.description: The list of DNS answer header flag IDs.

flags.caption: DNS Header Flags
flags.description: The list of DNS answer header flags.

type.description: The type of data contained in this resource record. See RFC1035. For example: CNAME.

dns_query.caption: DNS Query
dns_query.description: The DNS query object represents a specific request made to the Domain Name System (DNS) to retrieve information about a domain or perform a DNS operation. This object encapsulates the necessary attributes and methods to construct and send DNS queries, specify the query type (e.g., A, AAAA, MX).
dns_query.name: dns_query

hostname.description: The hostname or domain being queried. For example: www.example.com

domain_contact.caption: Domain Contact
domain_contact.description: The contact information related to a domain registration, e.g., registrant, administrator, abuse, billing, or technical contact.
domain_contact.name: domain_contact

location.caption: Contact Location Information
location.description: Location details for the contract such as the city, state/province, country, etc.

name.description: The individual or organization name for the contact.

type.caption: Domain Contact Type
type.description: The Domain Contact type, normalized to the caption of the type_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the source

type_id.caption: Domain Contact Type ID
type_id.description: The normalized domain contact type ID.

1.caption: Registrant
1.description: The contact information provided is for the domain registrant.

2.caption: Administrative
2.description: The contact information provided is for the domain administrator.

3.caption: Technical
3.description: The contact information provided is for the domain technical lead.

4.caption: Billing
4.description: The contact information provided is for the domain billing lead.

5.caption: Abuse
5.description: The contact information provided is for the domain abuse contact.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the contact information, typically provided in WHOIS information.

edge.caption: Edge
edge.description: Represents a connection or relationship between two nodes in a graph.
edge.name: edge

data.description: Additional data about the edge such as weight, distance, or custom properties.

is_directed.description: Indicates whether the edge is (true) or undirected (false).

name.description: The human-readable name or label for the edge.

relation.description: The type of relationship between nodes (e.g. is-attached-to , depends-on, etc).

source.description: The unique identifier of the node where the edge originates.

target.description: The unique identifier of the node where the edge terminates.

uid.description: Unique identifier of the edge.

email.caption: Email
email.description: The Email object describes the email metadata such as sender, recipients, and direction, and can include embedded URLs and files.
email.name: email

files.description: The files embedded or attached to the email.

size.description: The size in bytes of the email, including attachments.

subject.caption: Subject
subject.description: The email header Subject value, as defined by RFC 5322.

uid.caption: Email Thread UID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the email thread.

urls.description: The URLs embedded in the email.

email_auth.caption: Email Authentication
email_auth.description: The Email Authentication object describes the Sender Policy Framework (SPF), DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM) and Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) attributes of an email.
email_auth.name: email_auth

encryption_details.caption: Encryption Details
encryption_details.description: Details about the encrytpion methodology utilized.
encryption_details.name: encryption_details

algorithm.caption: Encryption Algorithm
algorithm.description: The encryption algorithm used, normalized to the caption of 'algorithm_id

1.caption: DES
1.description: Data Encryption Standard Algorithm

2.caption: TripleDES
2.description: Triple Data Encryption Standard Algorithm

3.caption: AES
3.description: Advanced Encryption Standard Algorithm.

4.caption: RSA
4.description: Rivest-Shamir-Adleman Algorithm

5.caption: ECC
5.description: Elliptic Curve Cryptography Algorithm

6.caption: SM2
6.description: ShangMi Cryptographic Algorithm

key_length.caption: Encryption Key Length
key_length.description: The length of the encryption key used.

key_uid.description: The unique identifier of the key used for encrpytion. For example, AWS KMS Key ARN.

type.caption: Encryption Type
type.description: The type of the encryption used.

endpoint.caption: Endpoint
endpoint.description: The Endpoint object describes a physical or virtual device that connects to and exchanges information with a computer network. Some examples of endpoints are mobile devices, desktop computers, virtual machines, embedded devices, and servers. Internet-of-Things devices—like cameras, lighting, refrigerators, security systems, smart speakers, and thermostats—are also endpoints.
endpoint.name: endpoint

domain.description: The name of the domain that the endpoint belongs to or that corresponds to the endpoint.

hostname.description: The fully qualified name of the endpoint.

ip.description: The IP address of the endpoint, in either IPv4 or IPv6 format.

location.description: The geographical location of the endpoint.

mac.description: The Media Access Control (MAC) address of the endpoint.

name.description: The short name of the endpoint.

owner.description: The identity of the service or user account that owns the endpoint or was last logged into it.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The endpoint type. For example: unknown, server, desktop, laptop, tablet, mobile, virtual, browser, or other.

1.caption: Server
1.description: A server.

10.caption: Switch
10.description: A networking switch.

11.caption: Hub
11.description: A networking hub.

2.caption: Desktop
2.description: A desktop computer.

3.caption: Laptop
3.description: A laptop computer.

4.caption: Tablet
4.description: A tablet computer.

5.caption: Mobile
5.description: A mobile phone.

6.caption: Virtual
6.description: A virtual machine.

7.caption: IOT
7.description: An IOT (Internet of Things) device.

8.caption: Browser
8.description: A web browser.

9.caption: Firewall
9.description: A networking firewall.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the endpoint.

endpoint_connection.caption: Endpoint Connection
endpoint_connection.description: The Endpoint Connection object contains information detailing a connection attempt to an endpoint.
endpoint_connection.name: endpoint_connection

code.caption: Response Code
code.description: A numerical response status code providing details about the connection.

network_endpoint.description: Provides characteristics of the network endpoint.

enrichment.caption: Enrichment
enrichment.description: The Enrichment object provides inline enrichment data for specific attributes of interest within an event. It serves as a mechanism to enhance or supplement the information associated with the event by adding additional relevant details or context.
enrichment.name: enrichment

created_time.description: The time when the enrichment data was generated.

data.description: The enrichment data associated with the attribute and value. The meaning of this data depends on the type the enrichment record.

desc.description: A long description of the enrichment data.

name.description: The name of the attribute to which the enriched data pertains.

reputation.description: The reputation of the enrichment data.

short_desc.description: A short description of the enrichment data.

src_url.description: The URL of the source of the enrichment data.

type.description: The enrichment type. For example: location.

value.description: The value of the attribute to which the enriched data pertains.

name.description: The name of the environment variable.

value.description: The value of the environment variable.

epss.caption: EPSS
epss.description: The Exploit Prediction Scoring System (EPSS) object describes the estimated probability a vulnerability will be exploited. EPSS is a community-driven effort to combine descriptive information about vulnerabilities (CVEs) with evidence of actual exploitation in-the-wild. (EPSS).
epss.name: epss

created_time.description: The timestamp indicating when the EPSS score was calculated.

score.caption: EPPS Score
score.description: The EPSS score representing the probability [0-1] of exploitation in the wild in the next 30 days (following score publication).

version.description: The version of the EPSS model used to calculate the score.

evidences.caption: Evidence Artifacts
evidences.description: A collection of evidence artifacts associated to the activity/activities that triggered a security detection.
evidences.name: evidences

actor.description: Describes details about the user/role/process that was the source of the activity that triggered the detection.

api.description: Describes details about the API call associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

connection_info.description: Describes details about the network connection associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

container.description: Describes details about the container associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

data.description: Additional evidence data that is not accounted for in the specific evidence attributes. Use only when absolutely necessary.

database.description: Describes details about the database associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

databucket.description: Describes details about the databucket associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

device.description: An addressable device, computer system or host associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

dst_endpoint.description: Describes details about the destination of the network activity that triggered the detection.

email.description: The email object associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

file.description: Describes details about the file associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

http_request.description: Describes details about the http request associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

http_response.description: Describes details about the http response associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

ja4_fingerprint_list.description: Describes details about the JA4+ fingerprints that triggered the detection.

job.description: Describes details about the scheduled job that was associated with the activity that triggered the detection.

name.description: The naming convention or type identifier of the evidence associated with the security detection. For example, the @odata.type from Microsoft Graph Alerts V2 or display_name from CrowdStrike Falcon Incident Behaviors.

process.description: Describes details about the process associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

query.description: Describes details about the DNS query associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

resources.caption: Cloud Resources
resources.description: Describes details about the cloud resources directly related to activity that triggered the detection. For resources impacted by the detection, use Affected Resources at the top-level of the finding.

script.description: Describes details about the script that was associated with the activity that triggered the detection.

src_endpoint.description: Describes details about the source of the network activity that triggered the detection.

tls.description: Describes details about the Transport Layer Security (TLS) activity that triggered the detection.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the evidence associated with the security detection. For example, the activity_id from CrowdStrike Falcon Alerts or behavior_id from CrowdStrike Falcon Incident Behaviors.

url.description: The URL object that pertains to the event or object associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

user.description: Describes details about the user that was the target or somehow else associated with the activity that triggered the detection.

verdict.description: The normalized verdict of the evidence associated with the security detection.

verdict_id.description: The normalized verdict (or status) ID of the evidence associated with the security detection. For example, Microsoft Graph Security Alerts contain a verdict enumeration for each type of evidence associated with the Alert. This is typically set by an automated investigation process or an analyst/investigator assigned to the finding.

1.caption: False Positive
1.description: The verdict for the evidence has been identified as a False Positive.

2.caption: True Positive
2.description: The verdict for the evidence has been identified as a True Positive.

3.caption: Disregard
3.description: The verdict for the evidence is that is should be Disregarded.

4.caption: Suspicious
4.description: The verdict for the evidence is that the behavior has been identified as Suspicious.

5.caption: Benign
5.description: The verdict for the evidence is that the behavior has been identified as Benign.

6.caption: Test
6.description: The evidence is part of a Test, or other sanctioned behavior(s).

7.caption: Insufficient Data
7.description: There is insufficient data to render a verdict on the evidence.

8.caption: Security Risk
8.description: The verdict for the evidence is that the behavior has been identified as a Security Risk.

9.caption: Managed Externally
9.description: The verdict for the evidence is Managed Externally, such as in a case management tool.

10.caption: Duplicate
10.description: This evidence duplicates existing evidence related to this finding.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

extension.caption: Schema Extension
extension.description: The OCSF Schema Extension object provides detailed information about the schema extension used to construct the event. The schema extensions are registered in the extensions.md file.
extension.name: extension

name.description: The schema extension name. For example: dev.

uid.description: The schema extension unique identifier. For example: 999.

version.description: The schema extension version. For example: 1.0.0-alpha.2.

feature.caption: Feature
feature.description: The Feature object provides information about the software product feature that generated a specific event. It encompasses details related to the capabilities, components, user interface (UI) design, and performance upgrades associated with the feature.
feature.name: feature

name.description: The name of the feature.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the feature.

version.description: The version of the feature.

file.caption: File
file.description: The File object represents the metadata associated with a file stored in a computer system. It encompasses information about the file itself, including its attributes, properties, and organizational details.
file.name: file

created_time.description: The time when the file was created.

creator.description: The user that created the file.

desc.description: The description of the file, as returned by file system. For example: the description as returned by the Unix file command or the Windows file type.

encryption_details.description: The encryption details of the file. Should be populated if the file is encrypted.

ext.caption: File Extension
ext.description: The extension of the file, excluding the leading dot. For example: exe from svchost.exe, or gz from export.tar.gz.

internal_name.description: The name of the file as identified within the file itself. This contrasts with the name by which the file is known on disk. Where available, the internal name is widely used by security practitioners and detection content because the on-disk file name is not reliable. On the Windows OS, most PE files contain a VERSIONINFO resource from which the internal name can be obtained. On macOS, binaries can optionally embed a copy of the application's Info.plist file which in turn contains the name of the executable.

is_deleted.description: Indicates if the file was deleted from the filesystem.

is_encrypted.description: Indicates if the file is encrypted.

is_public.description: Indicates if the file is publicly accessible. For example in an object's public access in AWS S3

modified_time.description: The time when the file was last modified.

modifier.description: The user that last modified the file.

name.description: The name of the file. For example: svchost.exe

path.description: The full path to the file. For example: c:\windows\system32\svchost.exe.

product.description: The product that created or installed the file.

storage_class.description: The storage class of the file. For example in AWS S3: STANDARD, STANDARD_IA, GLACIER.

tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the file.

type.description: The file type.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the file as defined by the storage system, such the file system file ID.

url.description: The URL of the file, when applicable.

uri.caption: File URI
uri.description: The file URI, such as those reporting by static analysis tools. E.g., file:///C:/dev/sarif/sarif-tutorials/samples/Introduction/simple-example.js

volume.description: The volume on the storage device where the file is located.

version.description: The file version. For example: 8.0.7601.17514.

finding.caption: Finding
finding.description: The Finding object describes metadata related to a security finding generated by a security tool or system.
finding.name: finding

created_time.description: The time when the finding was created.

desc.description: The description of the reported finding.

first_seen_time.description: The time when the finding was first observed.

last_seen_time.description: The time when the finding was most recently observed.

modified_time.description: The time when the finding was last modified.

product.description: Details about the product that reported the finding.

product_uid.description: The unique identifier of the product that reported the finding.

src_url.description: The URL pointing to the source of the finding.

title.description: A title or a brief phrase summarizing the reported finding.

types.description: One or more types of the reported finding.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the reported finding.

finding_info.caption: Finding Information
finding_info.description: The Finding Information object describes metadata related to a security finding generated by a security tool or system.
finding_info.name: finding_info

attacks.description: The MITRE ATT&CK® technique and associated tactics related to the finding.

created_time.description: The time when the finding was created.

desc.description: The description of the reported finding.

first_seen_time.description:
The time when the finding was first observed. e.g. The time when a vulnerability was first observed.

It can differ from the created_time timestamp, which reflects the time this finding was created.

last_seen_time.description:
The time when the finding was most recently observed. e.g. The time when a vulnerability was most recently observed.

It can differ from the modified_time timestamp, which reflects the time this finding was last modified.

modified_time.description: The time when the finding was last modified.

product.description: Details about the product that reported the finding.

product_uid.description: The unique identifier of the product that reported the finding.

related_analytics.description: Other analytics related to this finding.

src_url.description: The URL pointing to the source of the finding.

tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated with the finding.

title.description: A title or a brief phrase summarizing the reported finding.

traits.description: The list of key traits or characteristics extracted from the finding.

types.description: One or more types of the reported finding.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the reported finding.

uid_alt.description: The alternative unique identifier of the reported finding.

fingerprint.caption: Fingerprint
fingerprint.description: The Fingerprint object provides detailed information about a digital fingerprint, which is a compact representation of data used to identify a longer piece of information, such as a public key or file content. It contains the algorithm and value of the fingerprint, enabling efficient and reliable identification of the associated data.
fingerprint.name: fingerprint

algorithm.description: The hash algorithm used to create the digital fingerprint, normalized to the caption of algorithm_id. In the case of Other, it is defined by the event source.

algorithm_id.description: The identifier of the normalized hash algorithm, which was used to create the digital fingerprint.

1.caption: MD5
1.description: MD5 message-digest algorithm producing a 128-bit (16-byte) hash value.

2.caption: SHA-1
2.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 1 producing a 160-bit (20-byte) hash value.

3.caption: SHA-256
3.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 2 producing a 256-bit (32-byte) hash value.

4.caption: SHA-512
4.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 2 producing a 512-bit (64-byte) hash value.

5.caption: CTPH
5.description: The ssdeep generated fuzzy checksum. Also known as Context Triggered Piecewise Hash (CTPH).

6.caption: TLSH
6.description: The TLSH fuzzy hashing algorithm.

7.caption: quickXorHash
7.description: Microsoft simple non-cryptographic hash algorithm that works by XORing the bytes in a circular-shifting fashion.

firewall_rule.caption: Firewall Rule
firewall_rule.description: The Firewall Rule object represents a specific rule within a firewall policy or event. It contains information about a rule's configuration, properties, and associated actions that define how network traffic is handled by the firewall.
firewall_rule.name: firewall_rule

duration.description: The rule response time duration, usually used for challenge completion time.

graph.caption: Graph
graph.description: A graph data structure representation with nodes and edges.
graph.name: graph

desc.description: The graph description - provides additional details about the graph's purpose and contents.

edges.description: The edges/connections between nodes in the graph - contains the collection of edge objects defining relationships between nodes.

is_directed.description: Indicates if the graph is directed (true) or undirected (false).

name.description: The graph name - a human readable identifier for the graph.

nodes.description: The nodes/vertices of the graph - contains the collection of node objects that make up the graph.

query_language.description: The graph query language, normalized to the caption of the query_language_id value.

query_language_id.description: The normalized identifier of a graph query language that can be used to interact with the graph.

1.caption: Cypher
1.description: A declarative graph query language developed by Neo4j that allows for expressive and efficient querying of graph databases.

2.caption: GraphQL
2.description: A query language for APIs that enables declarative data fetching and provides a complete description of the data in the API.

3.caption: Gremlin
3.description: A graph traversal language and virtual machine developed by Apache TinkerPop that enables graph computing across different graph databases.

4.caption: GQL
4.description: An ISO standard graph query language designed to provide a unified way to query graph databases.

5.caption: G-CORE
5.description: A graph query language that combines features from existing languages while adding support for paths as first-class citizens.

6.caption: PGQL
6.description: Property Graph Query Language developed by Oracle that provides SQL-like syntax for querying property graphs.

7.caption: SPARQL
7.description: A semantic query language for databases that enables querying and manipulating data stored in RDF format.

type.description: The graph type. Typically useful to represent the specifc type of graph that is used.

uid.description: Unique identifier of the graph - a unique ID to reference this specific graph.

group.caption: Group
group.description: The Group object represents a collection or association of entities, such as users, policies, or devices. It serves as a logical grouping mechanism to organize and manage entities with similar characteristics or permissions within a system or organization, including but not limited to purposes of access control.
group.name: group

desc.description: The group description.

domain.description: The domain where the group is defined. For example: the LDAP or Active Directory domain.

name.description: The group name.

type.caption: Account Type
type.description: The type of the group or account.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the group. For example, for Windows events this is the security identifier (SID) of the group.

hassh.caption: HASSH
hassh.description: The HASSH object contains SSH network fingerprinting values for specific client/server implementations. It provides a standardized way of identifying and categorizing SSH connections based on their unique characteristics and behavior.
hassh.name: hassh

algorithm.description: The concatenation of key exchange, encryption, authentication and compression algorithms (separated by ';'). NOTE: This is not the underlying algorithm for the hash implementation.

fingerprint.description: The hash of the key exchange, encryption, authentication and compression algorithms.

http_cookie.caption: HTTP Cookie
http_cookie.description: The HTTP Cookie object, also known as a web cookie or browser cookie, contains details and values pertaining to a small piece of data that a server sends to a user's web browser. This data is then stored by the browser and sent back to the server with subsequent requests, allowing the server to remember and track certain information about the user's browsing session or preferences.
http_cookie.name: http_cookie

domain.description: The domain name for the server from which the http_cookie is served.

expiration_time.description: The expiration time of the HTTP cookie.

name.description: The HTTP cookie name.

path.description: The path of the HTTP cookie.

http_header.caption: HTTP Header
http_header.description: The HTTP Header object represents the headers sent in an HTTP request or response. HTTP headers are key-value pairs that convey additional information about the HTTP message, including details about the content, caching, authentication, encoding, and other aspects of the communication.
http_header.name: http_header

name.description: The name of the HTTP header.

value.description: The value of the HTTP header.

http_request.caption: HTTP Request
http_request.description: The HTTP Request object represents the attributes of a request made to a web server. It encapsulates the details and metadata associated with an HTTP request, including the request method, headers, URL, query parameters, body content, and other relevant information.
http_request.name: http_request

body_length.caption: Request Body Length
body_length.description: The actual length of the HTTP request body, in number of bytes, independent of a potentially existing Content-Length header.

http_method.caption: HTTP Method
http_method.description: The HTTP request method indicates the desired action to be performed for a given resource.

CONNECT.caption: Connect
CONNECT.description: The CONNECT method establishes a tunnel to the server identified by the target resource.

DELETE.caption: Delete
DELETE.description: The DELETE method deletes the specified resource.

GET.caption: Get
GET.description: The GET method requests a representation of the specified resource. Requests using GET should only retrieve data.

HEAD.caption: Head
HEAD.description: The HEAD method asks for a response identical to a GET request, but without the response body.

OPTIONS.caption: Options
OPTIONS.description: The OPTIONS method describes the communication options for the target resource.

POST.caption: Post
POST.description: The POST method submits an entity to the specified resource, often causing a change in state or side effects on the server.

PUT.caption: Put
PUT.description: The PUT method replaces all current representations of the target resource with the request payload.

TRACE.caption: Trace
TRACE.description: The TRACE method performs a message loop-back test along the path to the target resource.

length.caption: Request Length
length.description: The length of the entire HTTP request, in number of bytes.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the http request.

url.description: The URL object that pertains to the request.

version.caption: HTTP Version
version.description: The Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) version.

http_response.caption: HTTP Response
http_response.description: The HTTP Response object contains detailed information about the response sent from a web server to the requester. It encompasses attributes and metadata that describe the response status, headers, body content, and other relevant information.
http_response.name: http_response

body_length.caption: Response Body Length
body_length.description: The actual length of the HTTP response body, in number of bytes, independent of a potentially existing Content-Length header.

code.description: The Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) status code returned from the web server to the client. For example, 200.

length.caption: Response Length
length.description: The length of the entire HTTP response, in number of bytes.

status.description: The response status. For example: A successful HTTP status of 'OK' which corresponds to a code of 200.

idp.caption: Identity Provider
idp.description: The Identity Provider object contains detailed information about a provider responsible for creating, maintaining, and managing identity information while offering authentication services to applications. An Identity Provider (IdP) serves as a trusted authority that verifies the identity of users and issues authentication tokens or assertions to enable secure access to applications or services.
idp.name: idp

auth_factors.description: The Authentication Factors object describes the different types of Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) methods and/or devices supported by the Identity Provider.

domain.description: The primary domain associated with the Identity Provider.

fingerprint.caption: Certificate Fingerprint
fingerprint.description: The fingerprint of the X.509 certificate used by the Identity Provider.

has_mfa.caption: MFA Enforced
has_mfa.description: The Identity Provider enforces Multi Factor Authentication (MFA).

issuer.description: The unique identifier (often a URL) used by the Identity Provider as its issuer.

name.description: The name of the Identity Provider.

protocol_name.caption: Supported Protocol
protocol_name.description: The supported protocol of the Identity Provider. E.g., SAML, OIDC, or OAuth2.

state.description: The configuration state of the Identity Provider, normalized to the caption of the state_id value. In the case of Other, it is defined by the event source.

state_id.description: The normalized state ID of the Identity Provider to reflect its configuration or activation status.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The configuration state of the Identity Provider is unknown.

1.caption: Active
1.description: The Identity Provider is in an Active state, or otherwise enabled.

2.caption: Suspended
2.description: The Identity Provider is in a Suspended state.

3.caption: Deprecated
3.description: The Identity Provider is in a Deprecated state, or is otherwise disabled.

4.caption: Deleted
4.description: The Identity Provider is in a Deleted state.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The configuration state of the Identity Provider is not mapped. See the state attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

tenant_uid.description: The tenant ID associated with the Identity Provider.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the Identity Provider.

url_string.caption: Configuration URL
url_string.description: The URL for accessing the configuration or metadata of the Identity Provider.

image.caption: Image
image.description: The Image object provides a description of a specific Virtual Machine (VM) or Container image.
image.name: image

labels.description: The list of labels associated to the image.

name.description: The image name. For example: elixir.

path.description: The full path to the image file.

tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the image.

uid.description: The unique image ID. For example: 77af4d6b9913.

ja4_fingerprint.caption: JA4+ Fingerprint
ja4_fingerprint.description: The JA4+ fingerprint object provides detailed fingerprint information about various aspects of network traffic which is both machine and human readable.
ja4_fingerprint.name: ja4_fingerprint

type.description: The JA4+ fingerprint type as defined by FoxIO, normalized to the caption of 'type_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

type_id.description: The identifier of the JA4+ fingerprint type.

1.caption: JA4
1.description: TLS Client Fingerprint.

2.caption: JA4Server
2.description: TLS Server Response/Session Fingerprint.

3.caption: JA4HTTP
3.description: HTTP Client Fingerprint.

4.caption: JA4Latency
4.description: Latency Measurement/Light Distance Fingerprint.

5.caption: JA4X509
5.description: X509 TLS Certificate Fingerprint.

6.caption: JA4SSH
6.description: SSH Traffic Fingerprint.

7.caption: JA4TCP
7.description: Passive TCP Client Fingerprint.

8.caption: JA4TCPServer
8.description: Passive TCP Server Fingerprint.

9.caption: JA4TCPScan
9.description: Active TCP Server Fingerprint.

job.caption: Job
job.description: The Job object provides information about a scheduled job or task, including its name, command line, and state. It encompasses attributes that describe the properties and status of the scheduled job.
job.name: job

created_time.description: The time when the job was created.

desc.description: The description of the job.

file.description: The file that pertains to the job.

last_run_time.description: The time when the job was last run.

name.description: The name of the job.

next_run_time.description: The time when the job will next be run.

run_state.description: The run state of the job.

run_state_id.description: The run state ID of the job.

user.description: The user that created the job.

kb_article.caption: KB Article
kb_article.description: The KB Article object contains metadata that describes the patch or update.
kb_article.name: kb_article

classification.description: The vendors classification of the kb article.

created_time.description: The date the kb article was released by the vendor.

install_state.description: The install state of the kb article.

install_state_id.description: The normalized install state ID of the kb article.

is_superseded.description: The kb article has been replaced by another.

os.description: The operating system the kb article applies.

product.description: The product details the kb article applies.

severity.description: The severity of the kb article.

size.description: The size in bytes for the kb article.

src_url.description: The kb article link from the source vendor.

title.description: The title of the kb article.

uid.description: The unique identifier for the kb article.

kernel.caption: Kernel Resource
kernel.description: The Kernel Resource object provides information about a specific kernel resource, including its name and type. It describes essential attributes associated with a resource managed by the kernel of an operating system.
kernel.name: kernel

name.description: The name of the kernel resource.

path.description: The full path of the kernel resource.

type.description: The type of the kernel resource.

type_id.description: The type of the kernel resource.

kernel_driver.caption: Kernel Extension
kernel_driver.description: The Kernel Extension object describes a kernel driver that has been loaded or unloaded into the operating system (OS) kernel.
kernel_driver.name: kernel_driver

file.description: The driver/extension file object.

key_value_object.caption: Key:Value object
key_value_object.description: A generic object allowing to define a {key:value} pair.
key_value_object.name: key_value_object

name.description: The name of the key.

value.description: The value associated to the key.

values.description: Optional, the values associated to the key. You can populate this attribute, when you have multiple values for the same key.

keyboard_info.caption: Keyboard Information
keyboard_info.description: The Keyboard Information object contains details and attributes related to a computer or device keyboard. It encompasses information that describes the characteristics, capabilities, and configuration of the keyboard.
keyboard_info.name: keyboard_info

kill_chain_phase.caption: Kill Chain Phase
kill_chain_phase.description: The Kill Chain Phase object represents a single phase of a cyber attack, including the initial reconnaissance and planning stages up to the final objective of the attacker. It provides a detailed description of each phase and its associated activities within the broader context of a cyber attack. See Cyber Kill Chain®.
kill_chain_phase.name: kill_chain_phase

ldap_person.caption: LDAP Person
ldap_person.description: The additional LDAP attributes that describe a person.
ldap_person.name: ldap_person

created_time.description: The timestamp when the user was created.

display_name.description: The display name of the LDAP person. According to RFC 2798, this is the preferred name of a person to be used when displaying entries.

labels.description: The labels associated with the user. For example in AD this could be the userType, employeeType. For example: Member, Employee.

location.description: The geographical location associated with a user. This is typically the user's usual work location.

modified_time.description: The timestamp when the user entry was last modified.

phone_number.caption: Telephone Number
phone_number.description: The telephone number of the user. Corresponds to the LDAP Telephone-Number CN.

tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the user.

load_balancer.caption: Load Balancer
load_balancer.description: The load balancer object describes the load balancer entity and contains additional information regarding the distribution of traffic across a network.
load_balancer.name: load_balancer

classification.caption: Classification
classification.description: The request classification as defined by the load balancer.

code.caption: Response Code
code.description: The numeric response status code detailing the connection from the load balancer to the destination target.

dst_endpoint.caption: Destination Endpoint
dst_endpoint.description: The destination to which the load balancer is distributing traffic.

endpoint_connections.caption: Endpoint Connections
endpoint_connections.description: An object detailing the load balancer connection attempts and responses.

ip.description: The IP address of the load balancer node that handled the client request. Note: the load balancer may have other IP addresses, and this is not an IP address of the target/distribution endpoint - see dst_endpoint.

metrics.caption: Metrics
metrics.description: General purpose metrics associated with the load balancer.

name.description: The name of the load balancer.

status_detail.caption: Status Detail
status_detail.description: The status detail contains additional status information about the load balancer distribution event.

uid.description: The unique identifier for the load balancer.

location.caption: Geo Location
location.description: The Geo Location object describes a geographical location, usually associated with an IP address.
location.name: location

desc.description: The description of the geographical location.

@deprecated.message: Utilize isp attribute available in network_endpoint, whois objects according to your use-case.

provider.description: The provider of the geographical location data.

region.description: The alphanumeric code that identifies the principal subdivision (e.g. province or state) of the country. For example, 'CH-VD' for the Canton of Vaud, Switzerland

logger.caption: Logger
logger.description: The Logger object represents the device and product where events are stored with times for receipt and transmission.  This may be at the source device where the event occurred, a remote scanning device, intermediate hops, or the ultimate destination.
logger.name: logger

device.description: The device where the events are logged.

event_uid.description: The unique identifier of the event assigned by the logger.

name.description: The name of the logging product instance.

product.description: The product logging the event.  This may be the event source product, a management server product, a scanning product, a SIEM, etc.

transmit_time.description: The time when the event was transmitted from the logging device to it's next destination.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the logging product instance.

version.description: The version of the logging product.

long_string.caption: Long String
long_string.description: This object is a used to capture strings which may be truncated by a security product due to their length.
long_string.name: long_string

is_truncated.description: Indicates that value has been truncated. May be omitted if truncation has not occurred.

untruncated_size.description: The size in bytes of the string represented by value before truncation. Should be omitted if truncation has not occurred.

value.description: The string value, truncated if is_truncated is true.

malware.caption: Malware
malware.description: The Malware object describes the classification of known malicious software, which is intentionally designed to cause damage to a computer, server, client, or computer network.
malware.name: malware

classification_ids.description: The list of normalized identifiers of the malware classifications.

classifications.description: The list of malware classifications, normalized to the captions of the classification_ids values. In the case of 'Other', they are defined by the event source.

cves.description: The list of Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) identifiers associated with the malware. Reference: CVE

name.description: The malware name, as reported by the detection engine.

files.description: The list of file objects representing files that were identified as infected by the malware.

num_infected.description: The number of files that were identified to be infected by the malware.

path.description: The filesystem path of the malware that was observed.

provider.description: The name or identifier of the security solution or service that provided the malware detection information.

severity.description: The severity of the malware, normalized to the captions of the severity_id values. In the case of 'Other', they are defined by the event source.

severity_id.description: The normalized identifier of the malware severity.

uid.description: A unique identifier for the specific malware instance, as assigned by the detection engine (e.g., virus signature ID or IPS rule ID).

malware_scan_info.caption: Malware Scan Info
malware_scan_info.description: The malware scan information object describes characteristics, metadata of a malware scanning job.
malware_scan_info.name: malware_scan_info

end_time.description: The timestamp indicating when the scan job completed execution.

num_files.description: The total number of files analyzed during the scan.

num_infected.description: The total number of files identified as infected with malware during the scan.

num_volumes.description: The total number of storage volumes examined during the malware scan.

size.description: The total size in bytes of all files that were scanned.

start_time.description: The timestamp indicating when the scan job began execution.

unique_malware_count.description: The number of unique malware detected across all infected files.

managed_entity.caption: Managed Entity
managed_entity.description: The Managed Entity object describes the type and version of an entity, such as a user, device, or policy. For types in the type_id enum list, an associated attribute should be populated. If the type of entity is not in the type_id list, information can be put into the data attribute, type_id should be 'Other' and the type attribute should label the entity type.
managed_entity.name: managed_entity

data.description: The managed entity content as a JSON object.

name.description: The name of the managed entity. It should match the name of the specific entity object's name if populated, or the name of the managed entity if the type_id is 'Other'.

policy.description: Describes details of a managed policy.

type.description: The managed entity type. For example: Policy, User, Organization, Device.

type_id.description: The type of the Managed Entity. It is recommended to also populate the type attribute with the associated label, or the source specific name if Other.

1.caption: Device
1.description: A managed Device entity. This item corresponds to population of the device attribute.

2.caption: User
2.description: A managed User entity. This item corresponds to population of the user attribute.

3.caption: Group
3.description: A managed Group entity. This item corresponds to population of the group attribute.

4.caption: Organization
4.description: A managed Organization entity. This item corresponds to population of the org attribute.

5.caption: Policy
5.description: A managed Policy entity. This item corresponds to population of the policy attribute.

6.caption: Email
6.description: A managed Email entity. This item corresponds to population of the email attribute.

7.caption: Network Zone
7.description: A managed Network Zone entity. Populate the name attribute with the zone name and/or the uid attribute with the zone ID. Additional zone information can be added to the data attribute.

uid.description: The identifier of the managed entity. It should match the uid of the specific entity's object UID if populated, or the source specific ID if the type_id is 'Other'.

version.description: The version of the managed entity. For example: 1.2.3.

metadata.caption: Metadata
metadata.description: The Metadata object describes the metadata associated with the event.
metadata.name: metadata

labels.description: The list of labels attached to the event. For example: ["sample", "dev"]

modified_time.description: The time when the event was last modified or enriched.

tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the event.

uid.caption: Event UID
uid.description: The logging system-assigned unique identifier of an event instance.

version.description: The version of the OCSF schema, using Semantic Versioning Specification (SemVer). For example: 1.0.0. Event consumers use the version to determine the available event attributes.

metric.caption: Metric
metric.description: The Metric object defines a simple name/value pair entity for a metric.
metric.name: metric

name.description: The name of the metric.

mitigation.caption: MITRE Mitigation
mitigation.description: The MITRE Mitigation object describes the ATT&CK® or ATLAS™ Mitigation ID and/or name that is associated to an attack.
mitigation.name: mitigation

name.description: The Mitigation name that is associated with the attack technique. For example: Password Policies, or Code Signing.

src_url.description: The versioned permalink of the Mitigation. For example: https://attack.mitre.org/versions/v14/mitigations/M1027.

uid.description: The Mitigation ID that is associated with the attack technique. For example: M1027, or AML.M0013.

countermeasures.description: The D3FEND countermeasures that are associated with the attack technique. For example: ATT&CK Technique T1003 is addressed by Mitigation M1027, and D3FEND Technique D3-OTP.
