references.description: ATT&CK® Mitigation to D3FEND™ Technique Mappings

module.caption: Module
module.description: The Module object describes the load attributes of a module.
module.name: module

file.description: The module file object.

load_type_id.description: The normalized identifier for how the module was loaded in memory.

1.caption: Standard
1.description: A normal module loaded by the normal windows loading mechanism i.e. LoadLibrary.

2.caption: Non Standard
2.description: A module loaded in a way avoidant of normal windows procedures. i.e. Bootstrapped Loading/Manual Dll Loading.

3.caption: ShellCode
3.description: A raw module in process memory that is READWRITE_EXECUTE and had a thread started in its range.

4.caption: Mapped
4.description: A memory mapped file, typically created with CreatefileMapping/MapViewOfFile.

5.caption: NonStandard Backed
5.description: A module loaded in a non standard way. However, GetModuleFileName succeeds on this allocation.

type.description: The module type.

network_connection_info.caption: Network Connection Information
network_connection_info.description: The Network Connection Information object describes characteristics of an OSI Transport Layer communication, including TCP and UDP.
network_connection_info.name: network_connection_info

protocol_name.caption: Protocol Name
protocol_name.description: The IP protocol name in lowercase, as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA). For example: tcp or udp.

uid.caption: Connection UID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the connection.

network_endpoint.caption: Network Endpoint
network_endpoint.description: The Network Endpoint object describes characteristics of a network endpoint. These can be a source or destination of a network connection.
network_endpoint.name: network_endpoint

port.description: The port used for communication within the network connection.

proxy_endpoint.description: The network proxy information pertaining to a specific endpoint. This can be used to describe information pertaining to network address translation (NAT).

type.description: The network endpoint type. For example: unknown, server, desktop, laptop, tablet, mobile, virtual, browser, or other.

network_interface.caption: Network Interface
network_interface.description: The Network Interface object describes the type and associated attributes of a physical or virtual network interface.
network_interface.name: network_interface

hostname.description: The hostname associated with the network interface.

ip.description: The IP address associated with the network interface.

mac.description: The MAC address of the network interface.

name.description: The name of the network interface.

type.description: The type of network interface.

uid.description: The unique identifier for the network interface.

network_proxy.caption: Network Proxy Endpoint
network_proxy.description: The network proxy endpoint object describes a proxy server, which acts as an intermediary between a client requesting a resource and the server providing that resource.
network_proxy.name: network_proxy

network_traffic.caption: Network Traffic
network_traffic.description: The Network Traffic object describes characteristics of network traffic. Network traffic refers to data moving across a network at a given point of time.
network_traffic.name: network_traffic

chunks.description: The total number of chunks (in and out).

chunks_in.description: The number of chunks sent from the destination to the source.

chunks_out.description: The number of chunks sent from the source to the destination.

node.caption: Node
node.description: Represents a node or a vertex in a graph structure.
node.name: node

data.description: Additional data about the node stored as key-value pairs. Can include custom properties specific to the node.

desc.description: A human-readable description of the node's purpose or meaning in the graph.

name.description: A human-readable name or label for the node. Should be descriptive and unique within the graph context.

type.description: Categorizes the node into a specific class or type. Useful for grouping and filtering nodes.

uid.description: A unique string or numeric identifier that distinguishes this node from all others in the graph. Must be unique across all nodes.

object.caption: Object
object.description: An unordered collection of attributes. It defines a set of attributes available in all objects. It can be also used as a generic object to log objects that are not otherwise defined by the schema.
object.name: object

observable.caption: Observable
observable.description: The observable object is a pivot element that contains related information found in many places in the event.
observable.name: observable

name.description: The full name of the observable attribute. The name is a pointer/reference to an attribute within the OCSF event data. For example: file.name.

type.description: The observable value type name.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The observable data type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which may contain data source specific value.

value.description:
The value associated with the observable attribute. The meaning of the value depends on the observable type.
If the name refers to a scalar attribute, then the value is the value of the attribute.
If the name refers to an object attribute, then the value is not populated.

observation.caption: Observation
observation.description: A record of an observed value or event that captures the timing and frequency of its occurrence. Used to track when values/events were first detected, last detected, and their total occurrence count.
observation.name: observation

value.description: The specific value, event, indicator or data point that was observed and recorded. This is the core piece of information being tracked.

count.description: Integer representing the total number of times this specific value/event was observed across all occurrences. Helps establish prevalence and patterns.

timespan.description: The time window when the value or event was first observed. It is used to analyze activity patterns, detect trends, or correlate events within a specific timeframe.

occurrence_details.caption: Occurrence Details
occurrence_details.description: Details about where in the target entity, specified information was discovered. Only the attributes, relevant to the target entity type should be populuated.
occurrence_details.name: occurrence_details

cell_name.description: The cell name/reference in a spreadsheet. e.g A2

column_name.description: The column name in a spreadsheet, where the information was discovered.

column_number.description: The column number in a spreadsheet or a plain text document, where the information was discovered.

end_line.description: The line number of the last line of the file, where the information was discovered.

json_path.description: The JSON path of the attribute in a json record, where the information was discovered

page_number.description: The page number in a document, where the information was discovered.

record_index_in_array.description: The index of the record in the array of records, where the information was discovered. e.g. the index of a record in an array of JSON records in a file.

row_number.description: The row number in a spreadsheet, where the information was discovered.

start_line.description: The line number of the first line of the file, where the information was discovered.

organization.caption: Organization
organization.description: The Organization object describes characteristics of an organization or company and its division if any. Additionally, it also describes cloud and Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) logical hierarchies such as AWS Organizations, Google Cloud Organizations, Oracle Cloud Tenancies, and similar constructs.
organization.name: organization

name.description: The name of the organization, Oracle Cloud Tenancy, Google Cloud Organization, or AWS Organization. For example, Widget, Inc. or the AWS Organization name .

ou_name.description: The name of an organizational unit, Google Cloud Folder, or AWS Org Unit. For example, the GCP Project Name , or Dev_Prod_OU .

ou_uid.description: The unique identifier of an organizational unit, Google Cloud Folder, or AWS Org Unit. For example, an Oracle Cloud Tenancy ID , AWS OU ID , or GCP Folder ID .

uid.description: The unique identifier of the organization, Oracle Cloud Tenancy, Google Cloud Organization, or AWS Organization. For example, an AWS Org ID or Oracle Cloud Domain ID .

os.caption: Operating System (OS)
os.description: The Operating System (OS) object describes characteristics of an OS, such as Linux or Windows.
os.name: os

country.description:
The operating system country code, as defined by the ISO 3166-1 standard (Alpha-2 code).

Note: The two letter country code should be capitalized. For example: US or CA.

name.description: The operating system name.

type.description: The type of the operating system.

type_id.description: The type identifier of the operating system.

version.description: The version of the OS running on the device that originated the event. For example: "Windows 10", "OS X 10.7", or "iOS 9".

osint.caption: OSINT
osint.description: The OSINT (Open Source Intelligence) object contains details related to an indicator such as the indicator itself, related indicators, geolocation, registrar information, subdomains, analyst commentary, and other contextual information. This information can be used to further enrich a detection or finding by providing decisioning support to other analysts and engineers.
osint.name: osint

answers.caption: Related DNS Answers
answers.description: Any pertinent DNS answers information related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

attacks.description: MITRE ATT&CK Tactics, Techniques, and/or Procedures (TTPs) pertinent to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

autonomous_system.description: Any pertinent autonomous system information related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

comment.caption: Analyst Comments
comment.description: Analyst commentary or source commentary about an indicator or OSINT analysis.

confidence.description: The confidence of an indicator being malicious and/or pertinent, normalized to the caption of the confidence_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source or analyst.

confidence_id.description: The normalized confidence refers to the accuracy of collected information related to the OSINT or how pertinent an indicator or analysis is to a specific event or finding. A low confidence means that the information collected or analysis conducted lacked detail or is not accurate enough to qualify an indicator as fully malicious.

category.description: Categorizes the threat indicator based on its functional or operational role.

created_time.description: The timestamp when the indicator was initially created or identified.

creator.description: The identifier of the user, system, or organization that contributed the indicator.

desc.description: A detailed explanation of the indicator, including its context, purpose, and relevance.

email.caption: Related Email
email.description: Any email information pertinent to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

email_auth.caption: Related Email Authentication
email_auth.description: Any email authentication information pertinent to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

expiration_time.description: The expiration date of the indicator, after which it is no longer considered reliable.

file.caption: Related File
file.description: Any pertinent file information related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

detection_pattern.description: The specific detection pattern or signature associated with the indicator.

kill_chain.description: Lockheed Martin Kill Chain Phases pertinent to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

labels.description: Tags or keywords associated with the indicator to enhance searchability.

location.description: Any pertinent geolocation information related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

modified_time.description: The timestamp of the last modification or update to the indicator.

name.description: The name is a pointer/reference to an attribute within the OCSF event data. For example: file.name.

related_analytics.caption: Related Analytics
related_analytics.description: Any analytics related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

reputation.description: Related reputational analysis from third-party engines and analysts for a given indicator or OSINT analysis.

risk_score.description: A numerical representation of the threat indicator’s risk level.

references.description: Provides a reference to an external source of information related to the CTI being represented. This may include a URL, a document, or some other type of reference that provides additional context or information about the CTI.

script.caption: Related Script Data
script.description: Any pertinent script information related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

severity.description: Represents the severity level of the threat indicator, typically reflecting its potential impact or damage.

severity_id.description: The normalized severity level of the threat indicator, typically reflecting its potential impact or damage.

signatures.caption: Related Digital Signatures
signatures.description: Any digital signatures or hashes related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

src_url.description: The source URL of an indicator or OSINT analysis, e.g., a URL back to a TIP, report, or otherwise.

subdomains.caption: Related Subdomains
subdomains.description: Any pertinent subdomain information - such as those generated by a Domain Generation Algorithm - related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

subnet.caption: Related Subnet
subnet.description: A CIDR or network block related to an indicator or OSINT analysis.

tlp.caption: Traffic Light Protocol
tlp.description: The Traffic Light Protocol was created to facilitate greater sharing of potentially sensitive information and more effective collaboration. TLP provides a simple and intuitive schema for indicating with whom potentially sensitive information can be shared.

AMBER.caption: TLP:AMBER
AMBER.description: TLP:AMBER is for limited disclosure, recipients can only spread this on a need-to-know basis within their organization and its clients. Note that TLP:AMBER+STRICT restricts sharing to the organization only. Sources may use TLP:AMBER when information requires support to be effectively acted upon, yet carries risk to privacy, reputation, or operations if shared outside of the organizations involved. Recipients may share TLP:AMBER information with members of their own organization and its clients, but only on a need-to-know basis to protect their organization and its clients and prevent further harm. Note: if the source wants to restrict sharing to the organization only, they must specify TLP:AMBER+STRICT.

AMBER STRICT.caption: TLP:AMBER+STRICT
AMBER STRICT.description: TLP:AMBER is for limited disclosure, recipients can only spread this on a need-to-know basis within their organization and its clients. Note that TLP:AMBER+STRICT restricts sharing to the organization only. Sources may use TLP:AMBER when information requires support to be effectively acted upon, yet carries risk to privacy, reputation, or operations if shared outside of the organizations involved. Recipients may share TLP:AMBER information with members of their own organization and its clients, but only on a need-to-know basis to protect their organization and its clients and prevent further harm. Note: if the source wants to restrict sharing to the organization only, they must specify TLP:AMBER+STRICT.

CLEAR.caption: TLP:CLEAR
CLEAR.description: TLP:CLEAR denotes that recipients can spread this to the world, there is no limit on disclosure. Sources may use TLP:CLEAR when information carries minimal or no foreseeable risk of misuse, in accordance with applicable rules and procedures for public release. Subject to standard copyright rules, TLP:CLEAR information may be shared without restriction.

GREEN.caption: TLP:GREEN
GREEN.description: TLP:GREEN is for limited disclosure, recipients can spread this within their community. Sources may use TLP:GREEN when information is useful to increase awareness within their wider community. Recipients may share TLP:GREEN information with peers and partner organizations within their community, but not via publicly accessible channels. TLP:GREEN information may not be shared outside of the community. Note: when “community” is not defined, assume the cybersecurity/defense community.

RED.caption: TLP:RED
RED.description: TLP:RED is for the eyes and ears of individual recipients only, no further disclosure. Sources may use TLP:RED when information cannot be effectively acted upon without significant risk for the privacy, reputation, or operations of the organizations involved. Recipients may therefore not share TLP:RED information with anyone else. In the context of a meeting, for example, TLP:RED information is limited to those present at the meeting.

WHITE.caption: TLP:WHITE
WHITE.description: TLP:WHITE and TLP:CLEAR may be used interchangeably, TLP:WHITE is the most up to date (as of TLP 2.0) usage.

type.description: The OSINT indicator type.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The indicator type is ambiguous or there is not a related indicator for the OSINT object.

1.caption: IP Address
1.description: An IPv4 or IPv6 address.

10.caption: Vulnerability
10.description: A CVE ID, CWE ID, or other identifier for a weakness, exploit, bug, or misconfiguration.

11.caption: File
11.description: A file or metadata about a file.

The time when the finding was first observed. e.g. The time when a vulnerability was first observed.
It can differ from the created_time timestamp, which reflects the time this finding was created.

last_seen_time.description:
The time when the finding was most recently observed. e.g. The time when a vulnerability was most recently observed.
It can differ from the modified_time timestamp, which reflects the time this finding was last modified.

The type of the related event/finding.

Populate if the related event/finding is NOT in OCSF. If it is in OCSF, then utilize type_name, type_uid instead.

The type of the related OCSF event, as defined by type_uid.

For example: Process Activity: Launch.

The unique identifier of the related OCSF event type.

For example: 100701.

The unique identifier of the related event/finding.

span.caption: Span
span.description: Represents a single unit of work or operation within a distributed trace. A span typically tracks the execution of a request across a service, capturing important details such as the operation, timestamps, and status. Spans help break down the overall trace into smaller, manageable parts, enabling detailed analysis of the performance and behavior of specific operations within the system. They are crucial for understanding latency, dependencies, and bottlenecks in complex distributed systems.
span.name: span

duration.description: The total time, in milliseconds, that the span represents, calculated as the difference between start_time and end_time. It reflects the operation's performance and latency, independent of event timestamps, and accounts for normalized times used by observability tools to ensure consistency across distributed systems.

end_time.description: The end timestamp of the span, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. Like the start time, this timestamp is normalized across the observability system to ensure consistency, even when events are recorded across distributed services with unsynchronized clocks. Normalized time allows for accurate duration calculations and helps observability tools track performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.

message.description: The message in a span (often refered to as a span event) serves as a way to record significant moments or occurrences during the span's lifecycle. This content typically manifests as log entries, annotations, or semi-structured events as a string, providing additional granularity and context about what happens at specific points during the execution of an operation.

operation.description: Describes an action performed in a span, such as API requests, database queries, or computations.

parent_uid.description: The ID of the parent span for this span object, establishing its relationship in the trace hierarchy.

service.description: Identifies the service or component that generates the span, helping trace its path through the distributed system.

start_time.description: The start timestamp of the span, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. This timestamp is normalized across the observability system, ensuring consistency even when events occur across distributed services with potentially unsynchronized clocks. By using normalized time, observability tools can provide accurate, uniform measurements of operation performance and latency, regardless of where or when the events actually occur.

status_code.description: Indicates the outcome of the operation in the span, such as success, failure, or error. Issues in a span typically refer to problems such as failed operations, timeouts, service unavailability, or errors in processing that can negatively impact the performance or reliability of the system. Tracking the `status_code` helps pinpoint these issues, enabling quicker identification and resolution of system inefficiencies or faults.

uid.description: The unique identifier for the span, used in distributed systems and microservices architectures to track and correlate requests across different components of an application. It enables tracing the flow of a request through various services.

sso.caption: SSO
sso.description: The Single Sign-On (SSO) object provides a structure for normalizing SSO attributes, configuration, and/or settings from Identity Providers.
sso.name: sso

auth_protocol.description: The authorization protocol as defined by the caption of auth_protocol_id. In the case of Other, it is defined by the event source.

auth_protocol_id.description: The normalized identifier of the authentication protocol used by the SSO resource.

certificate.caption: SAML Certificate
certificate.description: Digital Signature associated with the SSO resource, e.g., SAML X.509 certificate details.

created_time.description: When the SSO resource was created.

duration_mins.caption: SSO Session Duration
duration_mins.description: The duration (in minutes) for an SSO session, after which re-authentication is required.

idle_timeout.caption: SSO Idle Timeout
idle_timeout.description: Duration (in minutes) of allowed inactivity before Single Sign-On (SSO) session expiration.

login_endpoint.caption: SSO Login Endpoint
login_endpoint.description: URL for initiating an SSO login request.

logout_endpoint.caption: SSO Logout Endpoint
logout_endpoint.description: URL for initiating an SSO logout request, allowing sessions to be terminated across applications.

metadata_endpoint.caption: SSO Metadata Endpoint
metadata_endpoint.description: URL where metadata about the SSO configuration is available (e.g., for SAML configurations).

modified_time.description: The most recent time when the SSO resource was updated.

name.description: The name of the SSO resource.

protocol_name.caption: Supported Protocol

vendor_name.caption: Service Provider
vendor_name.description: Name of the vendor or service provider implementing SSO. E.g., Okta, Auth0, Microsoft.

6.caption: Pause Pending

start_type_id.description: The start type ID of the startup item.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The startup item type.

1.caption: Kernel Mode Driver

2.caption: User Mode Driver
2.description: User mode driver.

3.caption: Service
3.description: A background process typically managed by the operating system, e.g., a service process on Windows or a systemd-managed daemon on Linux.

4.caption: User Mode Application

6.caption: System Extension
6.description: System extensions on macOS enables 3rd parties to extend the capabilities of macOS.

8.caption: Scheduled Job, Task
8.description: A job or task that runs on a configured schedule.

99.caption: Other

sub_technique.caption: MITRE Sub-technique
sub_technique.description: The MITRE Sub-technique object describes the ATT&CK® or ATLAS™ Sub-technique ID and/or name associated to an attack.

table.caption: Table
table.description: The table object represents a table within a structured relational database or datastore, which contains columns and rows of data that are able to be create, updated, deleted and queried.
table.name: table

created_time.description: The time when the table was known to have been created.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: The description of the table.

groups.description: The group names to which the table belongs.

modified_time.description: The most recent time when any changes, updates, or modifications were made within the table.

name.description: The table name, ordinarily as assigned by a database administrator.

size.description: The size of the data table in bytes.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the table.

tactic.caption: MITRE Tactic
tactic.description: The MITRE Tactic object describes the ATT&CK® or ATLAS™ Tactic ID and/or name that is associated to an attack.
tactic.name: tactic

name.description: The Tactic name that is associated with the attack technique. For example: Reconnaissance or ML Model Access.

src_url.description: The versioned permalink of the Tactic. For example: https://attack.mitre.org/versions/v14/tactics/TA0043/.

technique.caption: MITRE Technique
technique.description: The MITRE Technique object describes the ATT&CK® or ATLAS™ Technique ID and/or name associated to an attack.
technique.name: technique

name.description: The name of the attack technique. For example: Active Scanning or AI Model Inference API Access.

src_url.description: The versioned permalink of the attack technique. For example: https://attack.mitre.org/versions/v14/techniques/T1595/.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the attack technique. For example: T1595 or AML.T0040.

threat_actor.caption: Threat Actor
threat_actor.description: Threat actor is responsible for the observed malicious activity.
threat_actor.name: threat_actor

name.description: The name of the threat actor.

type.caption: Threat Actor Type
type.description: The classification of the threat actor based on their motivations, capabilities, or affiliations. Common types include nation-state actors, cybercriminal groups, hacktivists, or insider threats.

type_id.caption: Threat Actor Type ID
type_id.description: The normalized datastore resource type identifier.

0.caption: Unknown

ticket.caption: Ticket
ticket.description: The Ticket object represents ticket in the customer's IT Service Management (ITSM) systems like ServiceNow, Jira, etc.
ticket.name: ticket

status.description: The status of the ticket normalized to the caption of the status_id value. In the case of 99, this value should as defined by the source.

2.caption: In Progress

5.caption: Resolved
5.description: The ticket is resolved and a solution is implemented, pending confirmation or verification from the requestor.

6.caption: Closed

7.caption: Canceled
7.description: The ticket has been canceled and will not be processed.

8.caption: Reopened
8.description: The ticket was previously closed, but has been reopened.

status_details.description: A list of contextual descriptions of the status, status_id values.

type.caption: Ticket Type
type.description: The linked ticket type determines whether the ticket is internal or in an external ticketing system.

type_id.caption: Ticket Type ID
type_id.description: The normalized identifier for the ticket type.

uid.description: Unique identifier of the ticket.

timespan.caption: Time Span
timespan.description:
The Time Span object represents different time period durations. If a timespan is fractional, i.e. crosses one period, e.g. a week and 3 days, more than one may be populated since each member is of integral type. In that case type_id if present should be set to Other.

A timespan may also be defined by its time interval boundaries, start_time and end_time.
timespan.name: timespan

duration.description: The duration of the time span in milliseconds.

duration_days.description: The duration of the time span in days.

duration_hours.description: The duration of the time span in hours.

duration_mins.description: The duration of the time span in minutes.

duration_months.description: The duration of the time span in months.

duration_secs.description: The duration of the time span in seconds.

duration_weeks.description: The duration of the time span in weeks.

duration_years.description: The duration of the time span in years.

end_time.description: The end time or conclusion of the timespan's interval.

start_time.description: The start time or beginning of the timespan's interval.

type.caption: Time Span Type
type.description: The type of time span duration the object represents.

type_id.caption: Time Span Type ID
type_id.description: The normalized identifier for the time span duration type.

9.caption: Time Interval
9.description: The start_time and end_time should be set.

tls.caption: Transport Layer Security (TLS)
tls.description: The Transport Layer Security (TLS) object describes the negotiated TLS protocol used for secure communications over an establish network connection.
tls.name: tls

version.description: The TLS protocol version.

tls_extension.caption: TLS Extension
tls_extension.description: The TLS Extension object describes additional attributes that extend the base Transport Layer Security (TLS) object.
tls_extension.name: tls_extension

data.description: The data contains information specific to the particular extension type.

type.description: The TLS extension type. For example: Server Name.

type_id.description: The TLS extension type identifier. See The Transport Layer Security (TLS) extension page.

1.caption: maximum_fragment_length
1.description: The Maximum Fragment Length Negotiation extension.

10.caption: supported_groups
10.description: The Supported Groups extension.

14.caption: use_srtp
14.description: The Use SRTP data protection extension.

45.caption: psk_key_exchange_modes
45.description: The Pre-Shared Key Exchange Modes extension.

5.caption: status_request
5.description: The Certificate Status Request extension.

trace.caption: Trace
trace.description: The trace object contains information about a distributed trace,  which is crucial for observability. Traces are made up of one or more spans, which are individual units of work in application activity. Traces track the journey of a request as it moves through various services in a system, capturing key details like timing, status, and dependencies at each step. Traces provide insights into system performance, helping to identify latency, bottlenecks, and issues in complex, distributed environments.
trace.name: trace

duration.description: The total time, in milliseconds, that the trace covers, calculated as the difference between start_time and end_time. This duration helps assess the overall performance of a request as it travels across various services, and is essential for identifying latency and potential bottlenecks within the distributed system. The trace duration may differ from individual span durations due to the propagation and processing times of the trace as it spans multiple components.

end_time.description: The end timestamp of the trace, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. Like the start time, this timestamp is normalized across the trace system to ensure consistency, even when events are recorded across distributed services with unsynchronized clocks. Normalized time allows for accurate trace duration calculations and helps observability tools track overall performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.

flags.description: The flags associated with the trace, used to indicate specific properties or behaviors, such as whether the trace is sampled or if it has special handling. Flags help control how traces are processed, logged, and analyzed, providing valuable context for tracing and observability tools in identifying trace characteristics or specific tracking requirements.

service.description: Identifies the service or component generating the trace, helping to track and correlate the flow of requests through various parts of a distributed system. This information is essential for understanding the role and performance of specific services within the broader context of system operations and for diagnosing issues across different components.

span.description: Represents a single unit of work or operation within a distributed trace. A span typically tracks the execution of a request across a service, capturing important details such as the operation, timestamps, and status. Spans help break down the overall trace into smaller, manageable parts, enabling detailed analysis of the performance and behavior of specific operations within the system. They are crucial for understanding latency, dependencies, and bottlenecks in complex distributed systems.

start_time.description: The start timestamp of the trace, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. Like the end time, this timestamp is normalized across the trace system to ensure consistency, even when events are recorded across distributed services with unsynchronized clocks. Normalized time enables accurate trace duration calculations and helps observability tools track performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the trace used in distributed systems and microservices architecture to track and correlate requests across various components of an application.

trait.caption: Trait
trait.description: Describes a characteristic or feature of an entity that was observed. For example, this object can be used to represent specific characteristics derived from events or findings that can be surfaced as distinguishing traits of the entity in question.
trait.name: trait

category.description: The high-level grouping or classification this trait belongs to.

name.description: The name of the trait.

type.description: The type of the trait. For example, this can be used to indicate if the trait acts as a contributing factor (increases risk/severity) or a mitigating factor (decreases risk/severity), in the context of the related finding.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the trait.

transformation_info.caption: Transformation Info
transformation_info.description: The transformation_info object represents the mapping or transformation used.
transformation_info.name: transformation_info

lang.description: The transformation language used to transform the data.

name.description: The name of the transformation or mapping.

product.description: The product or instance used to make the transformation

uid.description: The unique identifier of the mapping or transformation.

url_string.description: The Uniform Resource Locator String where the mapping or transformation exists.

unmanned_aerial_system.caption: Unmanned Aerial System
unmanned_aerial_system.description: The Unmanned Aerial System object describes the characteristics, Position Location Information (PLI), and other metadata of Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) and other unmanned and drone systems used in Remote ID. Remote ID is defined in the Standard Specification for Remote ID and Tracking (ASTM Designation: F3411-22a) ASTM F3411-22a.
unmanned_aerial_system.name: unmanned_aerial_system

name.description: The name of the unmanned system as reported by tracking or sensing hardware.

serial_number.description: The serial number of the unmanned system. This is expressed in CTA-2063-A format.

type.description: The type of the UAS. For example, Helicopter, Gyroplane, Rocket, etc.

0.caption: Unknown/Undeclared
0.description: The UAS type is empty or not declared.

10.caption: Airship
10.description: E.g., a blimp.

11.caption: Free Fall/Parachute
11.description: Parachutes, or objects without any power or propulsion mechanism.

2.caption: Helicopter
2.description: Can also be a Multi-rotor Unmanned Aircraft (e.g., Quad-copter).

4.caption: Hybrid Lift
4.description: Fixed wing aircraft that can take off vertically.

uid.caption: UAS ID
uid.description: The primary identification identifier for an unmanned system. This can be a Serial Number (in CTA-2063-A format, the Registration ID (provided by the CAA, a UTM, or a unique Session ID.

uid_alt.caption: UAS Alternate ID
uid_alt.description: A secondary identification identifier for an unmanned system. This can be a Serial Number (in CTA-2063-A format, the Registration ID (provided by the CAA, a UTM, or a unique Session ID.

uuid.caption: UTM UUID
uuid.description: The Unmanned Aircraft System Traffic Management (UTM) provided universal unique ID (UUID) traceable to a non-obfuscated ID where this UTM UUID acts as a 'session id' to protect exposure of operationally sensitive information.

unmanned_system_operating_area.caption: Unmanned System Operating Area
unmanned_system_operating_area.description: The Unmanned System Operating Area object describes details about a precise area of operations for a UAS flight or mission.
unmanned_system_operating_area.name: unmanned_system_operating_area

count.description: Indicates the number of UAS in the operating area.

end_time.description: The date and time at which a group or an Intent-Based Network Participant operation ends. (This field is only applicable to Network Remote ID.)

locations.caption: Operating Polygon
locations.description: A list of Position Location Information (PLI) (latitude/longitude pairs) defining the area where a group or Intent-Based Network Participant operation is taking place. (This field is only applicable to Network Remote ID.)

start_time.description: The date and time at which a group or an Intent-Based Network Participant operation starts. (This field is only applicable to Network Remote ID.)

type.description: The type of operating area. For example, Takeoff Location, Fixed Location, Dynamic Location.

0.caption: Unknown/Undeclared
0.description: The UA type is empty or not declared.

url.caption: Uniform Resource Locator
url.description: The Uniform Resource Locator (URL) object describes the characteristics of a URL.
url.name: url

domain.description: The domain portion of the URL. For example: example.com in https://sub.example.com.

hostname.description: The URL host as extracted from the URL. For example: www.example.com from www.example.com/download/trouble.

path.description: The URL path as extracted from the URL. For example: /download/trouble from www.example.com/download/trouble.

resource_type.description: The context in which a resource was retrieved in a web request.

url_string.description: The URL string. See RFC 1738. For example: http://www.example.com/download/trouble.exe. Note: The URL path should not populate the URL string.

user.caption: User
user.description: The User object describes the characteristics of a user/person or a security principal.
user.name: user

account.description: The user's account or the account associated with the user.

display_name.description: The display name of the user, as reported by the product.

domain.description: The domain where the user is defined. For example: the LDAP or Active Directory domain.

full_name.description: The full name of the user, as reported by the product.

groups.description: The administrative groups to which the user belongs.

ldap_person.description: The additional LDAP attributes that describe a person.

name.description: The username. For example, janedoe1.

org.description: Organization and org unit related to the user.

phone_number.caption: Telephone Number
phone_number.description: The telephone number of the user.

type.description: The type of the user. For example, System, AWS IAM User, etc.

1.caption: User
1.description: Regular user account.

2.caption: Admin
2.description: Admin/root user account.

3.caption: System
3.description: System account. For example, Windows computer accounts with a trailing dollar sign ($).

uid.description: The unique user identifier. For example, the Windows user SID, ActiveDirectory DN or AWS user ARN.

uid_alt.description: The alternate user identifier. For example, the Active Directory user GUID or AWS user Principal ID.

vendor_attributes.caption: Vendor Attributes
vendor_attributes.description:
The Vendor Attributes object can be used to represent values of attributes populated by the Vendor/Finding Provider. It can help distinguish between the vendor-prodvided values and consumer-updated values, of key attributes like severity_id.
The original finding producer should not populate this object. It should be populated by consuming systems that support data mutability.
vendor_attributes.name: vendor_attributes

severity.description: The finding severity, as reported by the Vendor (Finding Provider). The value should be normalized to the caption of the severity_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the source.

severity_id.description: The finding severity ID, as reported by the Vendor (Finding Provider).

vulnerability.caption: Vulnerability Details
vulnerability.description: The vulnerability is an unintended characteristic of a computing component or system configuration that multiplies the risk of an adverse event or a loss occurring either due to accidental exposure, deliberate attack, or conflict with new system components.
vulnerability.name: vulnerability

category.description: The category of a vulnerability or weakness, as reported by the source tool, such as Container Security or Open Source Security.

cve.description: Describes the Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) details related to the vulnerability.

cwe.description: Describes the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) details related to the vulnerability.

desc.description: The description of the vulnerability.

first_seen_time.description: The time when the vulnerability was first observed.

fix_coverage.description: The fix coverage, normalized to the caption of the fix_coverage_id value.

fix_coverage_id.description: The normalized identifier for fix coverage, applicable to this vulnerability. Typically useful, when there are multiple affected packages but only a subset have available fixes.

1.caption: Complete
1.description: All affected packages and components have available fixes or patches to remediate the vulnerability.

2.caption: Partial
2.description: Only some of the affected packages and components have available fixes or patches, while others remain vulnerable.

3.caption: None
3.description: No fixes or patches are currently available for any of the affected packages and components.

last_seen_time.description: The time when the vulnerability was most recently observed.

references.description: A list of reference URLs with additional information about the vulnerability.

remediation.description: The remediation recommendations on how to mitigate the identified vulnerability.

severity.description: The vendor assigned severity of the vulnerability.

title.description: A title or a brief phrase summarizing the discovered vulnerability.

vendor_name.description: The name of the vendor that identified the vulnerability.

web_resource.caption: Web Resource
web_resource.description: The Web Resource object describes characteristics of a web resource that was affected by the activity/event.
web_resource.name: web_resource

data.description: Details of the web resource, e.g, file details, search results or application-defined resource.

desc.description: Description of the web resource.

name.description: The name of the web resource.

type.description: The web resource type as defined by the event source.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the web resource.

url_string.description: The URL pointing towards the source of the web resource.

whois.caption: WHOIS
whois.description: The resources of a WHOIS record for a given domain. This can include domain names, IP address blocks, autonomous system information, and/or contact and registration information for a domain.
whois.name: whois

autonomous_system.description: The autonomous system information associated with a domain.

created_time.caption: Registered At
created_time.description: When the domain was registered or WHOIS entry was created.

domain.description: The domain name corresponding to the WHOIS record.

email_addr.caption: Registrar Abuse Email Address
email_addr.description: The email address for the registrar's abuse contact

last_seen_time.caption: Last Updated At
last_seen_time.description: When the WHOIS record was last updated or seen at.

phone_number.caption: Registrar Abuse Phone Number
phone_number.description: The phone number for the registrar's abuse contact

status.caption: Domain Status
status.description: The status of a domain and its ability to be transferred, e.g., clientTransferProhibited.

subnet.caption: Subnet Block
subnet.description: The IP address block (CIDR) associated with a domain.

categories_meta.caption: Categories
categories_meta.description: The OCSF categories organize event classes, each aligned with a specific domain or area of focus.
categories_meta.name: category

application.caption: Application Activity
application.description: Application Activity events report detailed information about the behavior of applications and services.

discovery.caption: Discovery
discovery.description: Discovery events report the existence and state of devices, files, configurations, processes, registry keys, and other objects.

findings.caption: Findings
findings.description: Findings events report findings, detections, and possible resolutions of malware, anomalies, or other actions performed by security products.

iam.caption: Identity & Access Management
iam.description: Identity & Access Management (IAM) events relate to the supervision of the system's authentication and access control model. Examples of such events are the success or failure of authentication, granting of authority, password change, entity change, privileged use etc.

remediation.caption: Remediation
remediation.description: Remediation events report the results of remediation commands targeting files, processes, and other objects.

unmanned_systems.caption: Unmanned Systems
unmanned_systems.description: Unmanned Systems events report the activity, existence, and/or state of unmanned systems for tracking, mission planning, and other related activities.

dictionary.caption: Attribute Dictionary
dictionary.description: The Attribute Dictionary provides a comprehensive catalog of standardized attributes used across OCSF. It defines each attribute's properties, data types, and relationships. This dictionary serves as the authoritative reference for attribute definitions and ensures consistent usage throughout the schema.
dictionary.name: dictionary

timespan.caption: Time Span
timespan.description:
The Time Span object represents different time period durations. If a timespan is fractional, i.e. crosses one period, e.g. a week and 3 days, more than one may be populated since each member is of integral type. In that case type_id if present should be set to Other.

A timespan may also be defined by its time interval boundaries, start_time and end_time.

observation_parameter.caption: Observation Parameter
observation_parameter.description: The name of the parameter being analyzed or monitored. This generally identifies the specific characteristic or property being measured. See specific usage.

analysis_targets.caption: Analysis Targets
analysis_targets.description: The specific dimensions, components, or aspects of the system that are the targets of the analysis. See specific usage.

observations.caption: Observations
observations.description: A list of individual observations or measurements collected during analysis. Each observation captures a specific data point. See specific usage.

observation_type.caption: Observation Type
observation_type.description: The classification or category of the observation, indicating what kind of measurement or finding it represents. See specific usage.

observed_pattern.caption: Observed Pattern
observed_pattern.description: A detected pattern or trend identified in the analyzed data, describing recurring activities or characteristics.

anomalies.caption: Anomalies
anomalies.description: A list of detected anomalies or deviations from expected behavior patterns. See specific usage.

baselines.caption: Baselines
baselines.description: A list of baseline measurements or normal behavior patterns used as reference points for comparison and anomaly detection. See specific usage.

anomaly_analyses.caption: Anomaly Analyses
anomaly_analyses.description: A list of anomaly analysis results that examine and characterize patterns of activity or usage over time to identify normal vs abnormal activities. See specific usage.

access_list.caption: Access List
access_list.description: The list of requested access rights.

access_mask.caption: Access Mask
access_mask.description: The access mask in a platform-native format.

access_result.caption: Access Check Result
access_result.description: The list of access check results.

accessed_time.caption: Accessed Time
accessed_time.description: The time when the file was last accessed.

accessor.caption: Accessor
accessor.description: The name of the user who last accessed the object.

account.caption: Account
account.description: The account object describes details about the account that was the source or target of the activity.

ack_reason.caption: Acknowledgement Reason
ack_reason.description: An integer that provides a reason code or additional information about the acknowledgment result.

ack_result.caption: Acknowledgement Result
ack_result.description: An integer that denotes the acknowledgment result of the DCE/RPC call.

action.caption: Action
action.description: The normalized caption of 'action_id' or the source specific action.

action_id.caption: Action ID
action_id.description: The normalized action taken by a control or other policy-based system leading to an outcome or disposition.

1.caption: Allowed
1.description: The activity was allowed.

2.caption: Denied
2.description: The attempted activity was denied.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The action was not mapped. See the action attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

activity_id.caption: Activity ID
activity_id.description: The normalized identifier of the activity that triggered the event.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The event activity is not mapped. See the activity_name attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

activity_name.caption: Activity
activity_name.description: The event activity name, as defined by the activity_id.

actor.caption: Actor
actor.description: The actor object describes details about the user/role/process that was the source of the activity. Note that this is not the threat actor of a campaign but may be part of a campaign.

actual_permissions.caption: Actual Permissions
actual_permissions.description: The permissions that were granted in a platform-native format. See specific usage.

advisory.caption: Security Advisory
advisory.description: Detail about the security advisory, that is used to publicly disclose cybersecurity vulnerabilities by a vendor.

aerial_height.caption: Aerial Height
aerial_height.description: Expressed as either height above takeoff location or height above ground level (AGL) for a UAS current location. This value is provided in meters and must have a minimum resolution of 1 m. Special Values: Invalid, No Value, or Unknown: -1000 m.

affected_code.caption: Affected Code
affected_code.description: List of Affected Code objects that describe details about code blocks identified as vulnerable.

affected_packages.caption: Affected Software Packages
affected_packages.description: List of software packages identified as affected by a vulnerability/vulnerabilities.

agent.caption: Agent
agent.description: An Agent (also known as a Sensor) is typically installed on an Operating System (OS) and serves as a specialized software component that can be designed to monitor, detect, collect, archive, or take action. These activities and possible actions are defined by the upstream system controlling the Agent and its intended purpose. For instance, an Agent can include Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR) agents, backup/disaster recovery sensors, Application Performance Monitoring or profiling sensors, and similar software.

agent_list.caption: Agent List
agent_list.description: A list of agent objects associated with a device, endpoint, or resource.

aircraft.caption: Aircraft
aircraft.description: The Aircraft object represents any aircraft or otherwise airborne asset such as an unmanned system, airplane, balloon, spacecraft, or otherwise. The Aircraft object is intended to normalized data captured or otherwise logged from active radar, passive radar, multi-spectral systems, or the Automatic Dependant Broadcast - Surveillance (ADS-B), and/or Mode S systems.

alert.caption: Client TLS Alert
alert.description: The integer value of TLS alert if present. The alerts are defined in the TLS specification in RFC-2246.

algorithm.caption: Algorithm
algorithm.description: The applicable algorithm, normalized to the caption of 'algorithm_id'. See specific usage.

algorithm_id.caption: Algorithm ID
algorithm_id.description: The normalized identifier of the algorithm. See specific usage.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The algorithm is not mapped. See the algorithm attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

altitude_ceiling.caption: Altitude Ceiling
altitude_ceiling.description: Maximum altitude (WGS-84 HAE) for a group or an Intent-Based Network Participant. Measured in meters. Special Values: Invalid, No Value, or Unknown: -1000 m.

altitude_floor.caption: Altitude Floor
altitude_floor.description: Minimum altitude (WGS-84 HAE) for a group or an Intent-Based Network Participant. Measured in meters. Special Values: Invalid, No Value, or Unknown: -1000 m.

analytic.caption: Analytic
analytic.description: The analytic technique used to analyze and derive insights from the data or information that led to the finding or conclusion.

ancestry.caption: Ancestry
ancestry.description: An array of Process Entities describing the extended parentage of this process object. Direct parent information sould be expressed through the parent_process attribute. The first array element is the direct parent of this process object. Subsequent list elements go up the process parentage hierarchy. That is, the array is sorted from newest to oldest process. It is recommended to only populate this field for the top-level process object.

api.caption: API Details
api.description: Describes details about a typical API (Application Programming Interface) call.

app.caption: Application
app.description: The application that reported the event.

application.caption: Application
application.description: An Application describes the details for an inventoried application as reported by an Application Security tool or other Developer-centric tooling. Applications can be defined as Kubernetes resources, Containerized resources, or application hosting-specific cloud sources such as AWS Elastic BeanStalk, AWS Lightsail, or Azure Logic Apps.

app_name.caption: Application Name
app_name.description: The name of the application associated with the event or object.

app_uid.caption: Application ID
app_uid.description: The unique ID of the application associated with the event or object.

architecture.caption: Architecture
architecture.description: Architecture is a shorthand name describing the type of computer hardware the packaged software is meant to run on.

args.caption: HTTP Arguments
args.description: The arguments sent along with the HTTP request.

assignee.caption: Assignee
assignee.description: The details of the user assigned to an Incident.

assignee_group.caption: Assignee Group
assignee_group.description: The details of the group assigned to an Incident.

assessment.caption: Assessment
assessment.description: The Assessment object describes a point-in-time assessment, check, or evaluation of a specific configuration or signal against an asset, entity, person, or otherwise. For example, this can encapsulate os_signals from CrowdStrike Falcon Zero Trust Assessments, or account for Datastore configurations from Cyera.

assessments.caption: Assessments
assessments.description: A list of assessment objects. See specific usage.

attacks.caption: MITRE ATT&CK® and ATLAS™ Details
attacks.description: An array of MITRE ATT&CK® objects describing identified tactics, techniques & sub-techniques. The objects are compatible with MITRE ATLAS™ tactics, techniques & sub-techniques.

attributes.caption: Attributes
attributes.description: The bitmask value that represents the file attributes.

auth_factors.caption: Authentication Factors
auth_factors.description: Describes a category of methods used for identity verification in an authentication attempt.

auth_protocol.caption: Auth Protocol
auth_protocol.description: The authentication protocol as defined by the caption of auth_protocol_id. In the case of Other, it is defined by the event source.

auth_protocol_id.caption: Auth Protocol ID
auth_protocol_id.description: The normalized identifier of the authentication protocol used to create the user session.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The authentication protocol is not mapped. See the auth_protocol attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

auth_type.caption: Authentication Type
auth_type.description: The agreed upon authentication type, normalized to the caption of 'auth_type_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

auth_type_id.caption: Authentication Type ID
auth_type_id.description: The normalized identifier of the agreed upon authentication type. See specific usage.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The authentication type is not mapped. See the auth_type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

authentication_token.caption: Authentication Token
authentication_token.description: The authentication token, ticket, or assertion. See specific usage.

author.caption: Author
author.description: The author(s) who published the software component.

authorizations.caption: Authorization Information
authorizations.description: Provides details about an authorization, such as authorization outcome, and any associated policies related to the activity/event.

autonomous_system.caption: Autonomous System
autonomous_system.description: The Autonomous System details associated with an IP address.

autoscale_uid.caption: Autoscale UID
autoscale_uid.description: The unique identifier of the cloud autoscale configuration.

avg_timespan.caption: Average Timespan
avg_timespan.description: The average time span of an activity.

banner.caption: Protocol Banner
banner.description: The initial connection response that a messaging server receives after it connects to an email server.

base_address.caption: Base Address
base_address.description: The memory address where the module was loaded.

base_score.caption: Base Score
base_score.description: The base score as reported by the event source. See specific usage.

bios_ver.caption: BIOS Version
bios_ver.description: The BIOS version. For example: LENOVO G5ETA2WW (2.62).

body_length.caption: Body Length not including header
body_length.description: The actual length of the HTTP response/request body, in number of bytes, independent of a potentially existing Content-Length header.

boot_time.caption: Boot Time
boot_time.description: The time when the system was booted.

boot_uid.caption: Boot UID
boot_uid.description: A unique identifier of the device that changes after every reboot. For example, the value of /proc/sys/kernel/random/boot_id from Linux's procfs.

boundary.caption: Boundary
boundary.description:
The boundary of the connection, normalized to the caption of 'boundary_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary(same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.

boundary_id.caption: Boundary ID
boundary_id.description:
The normalized identifier of the boundary of the connection.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary (same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.

1.caption: Localhost
1.description: Local network traffic on the same endpoint.

2.caption: Internal
2.description: Internal network traffic between two endpoints inside network.

3.caption: External
3.description: External network traffic between two endpoints on the Internet or outside the network.

4.caption: Same VPC
4.description: Through another resource in the same VPC

5.caption: Internet/VPC Gateway
5.description: Through an Internet gateway or a gateway VPC endpoint

6.caption: Virtual Private Gateway
6.description: Through a virtual private gateway

7.caption: Intra-region VPC
7.description: Through an intra-region VPC peering connection

8.caption: Inter-region VPC
8.description: Through an inter-region VPC peering connection

9.caption: Local Gateway
9.description: Through a local gateway

10.caption: Gateway VPC
10.description: Through a gateway VPC endpoint (Nitro-based instances only)

11.caption: Internet Gateway
11.description: Through an Internet gateway (Nitro-based instances only)

99.caption: Other
99.description: The boundary is not mapped. See the boundary attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

bytes.caption: Total Bytes
bytes.description: The total number of bytes (in and out).

bytes_in.caption: Bytes In
bytes_in.description: The number of bytes sent from the destination to the source.

bytes_missed.caption: Bytes Missed
bytes_missed.description: Indicates the number of bytes missed, which is representative of packet loss.

bytes_out.caption: Bytes Out
bytes_out.description: The number of bytes sent from the source to the destination.

campaign.caption: Campaign
campaign.description: The campaign object describes details about the campaign that was the source of the activity.

caption.caption: Caption
caption.description: A short description or caption of the device. For example: Scanner 1 or Database Manager.

categories.caption: Website Categorization
categories.description: The Website categorization names, as defined by category_ids enum values.

category.caption: Category
category.description: The object category, normalized to the caption of category_id. See specific usage.

category_id.caption: Category ID
category_id.description: The normalized identifier of the object category. See specific usage.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The Domain/URL category is not mapped. See the categories attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

category_name.caption: Category
category_name.description: The event category name, as defined by category_uid value.

category_uid.caption: Category ID
category_uid.description: The category unique identifier of the event.

cc.caption: Cc
cc.description: The machine-readable email header Cc values, as defined by RFC 5322. For example example.user@usersdomain.com.

cc_mailboxes.caption: Cc Mailboxes
cc_mailboxes.description: The human-readable email header Cc Mailbox values. For example 'Example User <example.user@usersdomain.com>'.

cell_name.caption: Cell Name
cell_name.description: The name of the cell. See specific usage.

certificate.caption: Certificate
certificate.description: The certificate object containing information about the digital certificate.

certificate_chain.caption: Certificate Chain
certificate_chain.description: The Chain of Certificate Serial Numbers field provides a chain of Certificate Issuer Serial Numbers leading to the Root Certificate Issuer.

chassis.caption: Chassis
chassis.description: The chassis type describes the system enclosure or physical form factor. Such as the following examples for Windows Windows Chassis Types

checks.caption: Compliance Checks
checks.description: A list of specific, individual compliance verification checks derived from standard or non-standard benchmark rules or requirements.

chunks.caption: Chunks
chunks.description: A unit of information within an SCTP packet, consisting of a chunk header and chunk-specific content. See RFC 4960. This field can be used for the total number of chunks (in and out).

chunks_in.caption: Chunks In
chunks_in.description: A unit of information within an SCTP packet, consisting of a chunk header and chunk-specific content. See RFC 4960. This field can be used for the chunks sent from the destination to the source.

chunks_out.caption: Chunks Out
chunks_out.description: A unit of information within an SCTP packet, consisting of a chunk header and chunk-specific content. See RFC 4960. This field can be used for the chunks sent from the source to the destination.

cis_benchmark.caption: CIS Benchmark
cis_benchmark.description: The CIS Benchmark describes best practices for securely configuring IT systems, software, networks, and cloud infrastructure as defined by the Center for Internet Security (CIS).

@deprecated.message: Use Compliance object with Check object instead.

cis_benchmark_result.caption: CIS Benchmark Result
cis_benchmark_result.description: The CIS Benchmark Result object captures results generated from benchmark evaluations as defined by the Center for Internet Security (CIS).

@deprecated.message: Use Compliance object with Check object instead.

cis_controls.caption: CIS Controls
cis_controls.description: The CIS Critical Security Controls is a prioritized set of actions to protect your organization and data from cyber-attack vectors.

cis_csc.caption: CIS CSC
cis_csc.description: The CIS Critical Security Controls is a list of top 20 actions and practices an organization’s security team can take on such that cyber attacks or malware, are minimized and prevented.

@deprecated.message: Use CIS Controls for standard benchmark controls.

class.caption: Class
class.description: The class name of the object. See specific usage.

class_name.caption: Class
class_name.description: The event class name, as defined by class_uid value.

class_uid.caption: Class ID
class_uid.description: The unique identifier of a class. A class describes the attributes available in an event.

classification.caption: Classification
classification.description: The classification as defined by the vendor.

classification_ids.caption: Classification IDs
classification_ids.description: The list of normalized classification identifiers. See specific usage.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The classification is not mapped. See the classifications attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

classifications.caption: Classifications
classifications.description: The list of malware classifications, normalized to the captions of the classification_id values. In the case of 'Other', they are defined by the event source.

classifier_details.caption: Classifier Details
classifier_details.description: Describes details about the classifier used for data classification.

client_ciphers.caption: Client Cipher Suites
client_ciphers.description: The client cipher suites that were exchanged during the TLS handshake negotiation.

client_dialects.caption: Client Dialects
client_dialects.description: The list of SMB dialects that the client speaks.

cloud.caption: Cloud
cloud.description: Describes details about the Cloud environment where the event was originally created or logged.

cloud_partition.caption: Cloud Partition
cloud_partition.description: The canonical cloud partition name to which the region is assigned (e.g. AWS Partitions: aws, aws-cn, aws-us-gov).

cmd_line.caption: Command Line
cmd_line.description: The full command line used to launch an application, service, process, or job. For example: ssh user@10.0.0.10. If the command line is unavailable or missing, the empty string '' is to be used.

code.caption: Response Code
code.description: The numeric response sent to a request.

codes.caption: Response Codes
codes.description: The list of numeric responses sent to a request.

column_name.caption: Column Name
column_name.description: The name of the column. See specific usage.

column_number.caption: Column Number
column_number.description: The number of the column. See specific usage.

community_uid.caption: Community ID
community_uid.description: The Community ID of the network connection.

company_name.caption: Company Name
company_name.description: The name of the company that published the file. For example: Microsoft Corporation.

compliance.caption: Compliance
compliance.description: The compliance object provides context to compliance findings (e.g., a check against a specific regulatory or best practice framework such as CIS, NIST etc.) and contains compliance related details.

compliance_references.caption: Compliance Standard References
compliance_references.description: A list of reference KB articles that provide information to help organizations understand, interpret, and implement compliance standards. They provide guidance, best practices, and examples.

@deprecated.message: Use the Compliance object with Check array instead

compliance_standards.caption: Compliance Standards: Details
compliance_standards.description: A list of established guidelines or criteria that define specific requirements an organization must follow.

@deprecated.message: Use the Compliance object with Check array instead

component.caption: Component
component.description: The component of a data object. See specific usage.

condition.caption: Condition
condition.description: The rule trigger condition for the rule. For example: SQL_INJECTION.

confidence.caption: Confidence
confidence.description: The confidence, normalized to the caption of the confidence_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

confidence_id.caption: Confidence ID
confidence_id.description: The normalized confidence refers to the accuracy of the rule that created the finding. A rule with a low confidence means that the finding scope is wide and may create finding reports that may not be malicious in nature.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The confidence is not mapped to the defined enum values. See the confidence attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

confidence_score.caption: Confidence Score
confidence_score.description: The confidence score as reported by the event source.

confidentiality.caption: Confidentiality
confidentiality.description: The file content confidentiality, normalized to the confidentiality_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

confidentiality_id.caption: Confidentiality ID
confidentiality_id.description: The normalized identifier of the file content confidentiality indicator.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The confidentiality is not mapped. See the confidentiality attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

container.caption: Container
container.description: The information describing an instance of a container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.

containers.caption: Containers
containers.description: When working with containerized applications, the set of containers which write to the standard the output of a particular logging driver. For example, this may be the set of containers involved in handling api requests and responses for a containerized application.

content_type.caption: HTTP Content Type
content_type.description: The request header that identifies the original media type of the resource (prior to any content encoding applied for sending).

control.caption: Security Control
control.description: A Control is prescriptive, prioritized, and simplified set of best practices that one can use to strengthen their cybersecurity posture. e.g. AWS SecurityHub Controls, CIS Controls.

control_parameters.caption: Control Parameters
control_parameters.description: The list of control parameters evaluated in a Compliance check.

coordinates.caption: Coordinates
coordinates.description: A two-element array, containing a longitude/latitude pair. The format conforms with GeoJSON. For example: [-73.983, 40.719].

correlation_uid.caption: Correlation UID
correlation_uid.description: The unique identifier used to correlate events.

cost_center.caption: Cost Center
cost_center.description: The cost center associated with the user.

count.caption: Count
count.description: The number of times that events in the same logical group occurred during the event Start Time to End Time period.

countermeasures.caption: Countermeasures
countermeasures.description: The MITRE D3FEND™ Matrix Countermeasures associated with a remediation.

country.caption: Country
country.description:
The ISO 3166-1 Alpha-2 country code.

Note: The two letter country code should be capitalized. For example: US or CA.

cpe_name.caption: The product CPE identifier
cpe_name.description: The Common Platform Enumeration (CPE) name as described by (NIST) For example: cpe:/a:apple:safari:16.2.

cpu_architecture.caption: CPU Architecture
cpu_architecture.description: The CPU architecture, normalized to the caption of the cpu_architecture_id value. In the case of Other, it is defined by the source.

cpu_architecture_id.caption: CPU Architecture ID
cpu_architecture_id.description: The normalized identifier of the CPU architecture.

1.caption: x86
1.description: CPU uses the x86 ISA. For bitness, refer to cpu_bits.

2.caption: ARM
2.description: CPU uses the ARM ISA. For bitness, refer to cpu_bits.

3.caption: RISC-V
3.description: CPU uses the RISC-V ISA. For bitness, refer to cpu_bits.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The CPU architecture is not mapped. See the cpu_architecture attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

cpid.caption: Common Process Identifier
cpid.description: A unique process identifier that can be assigned deterministically by multiple system data producers.

cpu_bits.caption: CPU Bits
cpu_bits.description: The cpu architecture, the number of bits used for addressing in memory. For example: 32 or 64.

cpu_cores.caption: CPU Cores
cpu_cores.description: The number of processor cores in all installed processors. For Example: 42.

cpu_count.caption: CPU Count
cpu_count.description: The number of physical processors on a system. For example: 1.

cpu_speed.caption: Processor Speed
cpu_speed.description: The speed of the processor in Mhz. For Example: 4200.

cpu_type.caption: Processor Type
cpu_type.description: The processor type. For example: x86 Family 6 Model 37 Stepping 5.

create_mask.caption: Create Mask
create_mask.description: The original Windows mask that is required to create the object.

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The time when the object was created. See specific usage.

creator.caption: Creator
creator.description: The user that created the object associated with event. See specific usage.

credential_uid.caption: User Credential ID
credential_uid.description: The unique identifier of the user's credential. For example, AWS Access Key ID.

criticality.caption: Criticality
criticality.description: Criticality of a resource/object in question

cve.caption: CVE
cve.description: The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) identifiers for the vulnerability.

cves.caption: CVE List
cves.description: List of Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE).

cvss.caption: CVSS Score
cvss.description: The CVSS object details Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) scores from the advisory that are related to the vulnerability.

cwe.caption: CWE
cwe.description: The CWE object represents a weakness in a software system that can be exploited by a threat actor to perform an attack. The CWE object is based on the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) catalog.

cwe_uid.caption: CWE UID
cwe_uid.description: The Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) unique identifier. For example: CWE-787.

cwe_url.caption: CWE URL
cwe_url.description: Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) definition URL. For example: https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/787.html.

d3f_tactic.caption: MITRE D3FEND™ Tactic
d3f_tactic.description: The D3FEND Tactic object describes the defensive tactic name associated with a countermeasure.

d3f_technique.caption: MITRE D3FEND™ Technique
d3f_technique.description: The D3FEND Technique object describes the defensive technique ID and/or name associated with a countermeasure.

data.caption: Data
data.description: The additional data that is associated with the event or object. See specific usage.

data_classification.caption: Data Classification
data_classification.description: The Data Classification object includes information about data classification levels and data category types.

data_classifications.caption: Data Classification
data_classifications.description: A list of Data Classification objects, that include information about data classification levels and data category types, indentified by a classifier.

data_lifecycle_state.caption: Data Lifecycle State
data_lifecycle_state.description: The name of the stage or state that the data was in. E.g., Data-at-Rest, Data-in-Transit, etc.

data_lifecycle_state_id.caption: Data Lifecycle State ID
data_lifecycle_state_id.description: The stage or state that the data was in when it was assessed or scanned by a data security tool.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The data lifecycle state is unknown.

1.caption: Data at-Rest
1.description: The data was stored on physical or logical media and was not actively moving through the network nor was being processed. E.g., data stored in a database, PDF files in a file share, or EHR records in object storage.

2.caption: Data in-Transit
2.description: The data was actively moving through the network or from one physical or logical location to another. E.g., emails being send, data replication or Change Data Capture (CDC) streams, or sensitive data processed on an API.

3.caption: Data in-Use
3.description: The data was being processed, accessed, or read by a system, making it active in memory or CPU. E.g., sensitive data in a Business Intelligence tool, ePHI being processed in an EHR application or a user viewing data stored in a spreadsheet or PDF.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The data lifecycle state is not mapped. See the data_lifecycle_state attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

data_security.caption: Data Security
data_security.description: The Data Security object describes the characteristics, techniques and content of a Data Loss Prevention (DLP), Data Loss Detection (DLD), Data Classification, or similar tools' finding, alert, or detection mechanism(s).

data_sources.caption: Data Sources
data_sources.description: A list of data sources utilized in generation of the finding.

database.caption: Database
